PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
that the proposed capital gains tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural and small business sectors, which will severely affect their long term viability.

that the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament, full details of which still had not been revealed after it had legally been in operation for more than six months, has caused confusion and hindered farmers and small business people in the organisation of their affairs.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the capital gains tax legislation without delay and the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 104 citizens) and Chaney (from 26 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject any suggestion that family allowances be paid at a flat rate and instead should ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing payments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned, having great concern because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation call upon the Government to introduce immediate legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes with the open sale of only G, PG, and M rated video-cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale of R-rated video-cassettes so that R rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. We totally reject the concept of ``X'' rated video-cassettes which could allow the legal sale of hard-core pornographic films for screening in the homes of our nation, which endanger our children.

2. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and mailing by Australia Post so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film containing child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex, violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill:
1. Offer nothing more than is already available under law,
2. deny some Human Rights and do not include others,
3. give dangerously wide powers to an unelected body, and
4. could cause far more damage than they could possibly cure.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Senate should: Completely reject the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That we strongly support `The Australian Capital Territory Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill' introduced by Senator Evans, because it represents the first positive national step towards the eventual elimination of widespread serious ill health caused by smoking tobacco.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

(1) The Agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap may be terminated by either Government on one year's notice from 19 October 1986.
(2) In the event of war between the United States and the Soviet Union, access by the United States to Pine Gap makes it a probable nuclear target.
(3) Access by all nations to Pine Gap's capacity to monitor and verify compliance with existing and future nuclear limitations treaties could contribute to world peace and security.
(4) The people of Australia are entitled to be consulted, through their representatives in Parliament, on any extension or modification of the Agreement affecting their lives, security and welfare
and your petitioners humbly pray that:
(1) The Agreement between the United States and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap be terminated on one year from October 1986.

(2) Public discussion and inquiry be instituted into the feasibility of negotiating a new agreement with the United Nations during the International Year of Peace offering the verification facilities of the Pine Gap base to all nations.
(3) Any agreement concerning the future use of Pine Gap be referred to Parliament for ratification.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Coates (from nine citizens), Robertson (from seven citizens) and Tate (from eight citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operational Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by an employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Harradine (from 51 citizens) and Townley (from 90 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned members of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees' Association and Australian citizens respectfully showeth that:

1. The Sex Discrimination Act, passed by Parliament in 1984, will automatically make unenforceable from 1st August 1986 the weight lifting limits applicable to women employees and contained in State laws, regulations and awards.
2. These weight lifting limits have applied throughout Australia for many years and have acted to prevent many injuries at the workplace, thereby avoiding much suffering and loss of working time.
3. The removal of this protective legislation will increase the rate of injury among women employees and lead to greater Workers' Compensation costs for employees.
4. The weight lifting limits do not in any way hamper the achievement of equality and equal opportunity in employment for women employees in the workforce.
Your petitioners therefore pray that Parliament will amend the Sex Discrimination Act to enable the weight lifting limits for women employees to continue.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Leader of the Government in the Senate agree that the current national wage case could have a major impact on Australia's economic position and prospects? Does the postponement of this week's summit mean that the Government has given away any chance of asking the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to take the present perilous economic situation into account in making its far-reaching decision? If so, how does the Government justify this abrogation of its responsibility to do something effective about the economic situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree that this current national wage case is important. It is important to a variety of people for a variety of reasons. It is important under the accord because it represents a case which would provide indexed wages based on the consumer price index for the 1985 September and December quarters and an enormous time lag since those price increases were incurred in those quarters. So it is important to wage earners for that purpose. It is important to industry for different purposes because I take the view that, of course, in a sense it bears on the capacity of industry to be competitive-any increase does. That does not mean for a moment that there should not be increases, of course. The important thing about it all is that this wage case must be seen in the context of past wage cases and future wage cases. It is important that the Government has a prices and incomes policy which provides certainty, continuity and, as far as possible, wage restraint, which it has done. One has only to look at the effects in terms of reduction in real unit labour costs in the last two years to see that that effect has been taking place. Whether or not that is enough is a question which is currently the subject of some debate.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the second part of the question, whether the postponement of what Senator Chaney is pleased to call the summit set for later this week means that the Government has abdicated the possibility of making any impact on the current wage case, or in any way putting views to the Commission about the current wage case, the answer to that question is no.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. My supplementary question relates to the latter part of the Minister's answer. I ask the Minister can he clarify whether he is saying that the Government still may be going to submit further views on the economy to the Commission before it brings down its decision on the current wage case?

—Senator Chaney asked me a specific question: Does that mean that the Government will not have the opportunity to put anything to the national wage case? The answer to that question is no. Whether it will avail itself of that opportunity and in what form is not for me to say at this time.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has Australia made representations to the United States of America urging that country not to abandon the SALT II Treaty? If not, will the Minister for Foreign Affairs please make such representations on behalf of Australia and in the interests of world peace, especially in view of the attitude expressed by European members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation?

—As I indicated last week, Australia attaches very great importance to the existing regime of nuclear arms control, including the SALT II Treaty, because of the very important degree of predictability it establishes and because it does provide, even though not ratified by the United States Senate, a basis for negotiating new agreements to reduce the level of armaments, both nuclear and conventional. Australia is concerned about the United States decision not to be bound in the future by SALT II. The Prime Minister will be writing to President Reagan-if indeed he has not already; I have not been able to check out whether that letter was signed in the last 24 hours-as he has in the past to express Australia's concern that the principles of SALT II should be maintained as far as possible.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the concerns expressed by the Prime Minister at Canowindra on Saturday about the impact of the fringe benefits tax on the rural community and in particular as it affects accommodation provided on farms. Has the Prime Minister's promise to investigate the extent of the problems for farmers been referred to the Treasurer and considered by the Government? Does the Government intend to take any action either to discontinue the tax or to alleviate its impact on rural employers in the light of the fact that the legislation is before the Senate at the moment?

—I did not read anything about that matter, which I think was the question, although I did hear something about it. I am afraid I do not know. I will refer that to the Prime Minister and/or the Treasurer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, in recognition of the inflationary effects of the devaluation of the Australian dollar, have made submissions to the national wage case hearing that would reduce wage rises due to Australian workers by 2 per cent? Has the Australian work force accepted the need and urgency for discounting of wages and salaries? Have the professions, senior executives and others in receipt of large salaries also accepted the need for restraint on salaries, dividends and other forms of income? Finally, has the Minister's attention been brought to an article in the National Times of 30 May to 5 June headlined `Business executives get big rises while they urge wage restraint', and what is the Government's response to the contents of the article?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is, of course, a fact that the Government and the ACTU have recognised the need for discounting in the current national wage case. Everybody expects that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission will agree with that and that there will be a 2 per cent discount when the judgment is finally handed down. I think one can say with equal confidence that the Australian work force in general, certainly its peak council, has accepted the need and urgency in the general economic interests for that to happen.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the professions, senior executive and similar income recipients, it is more difficult to say with any degree of certainly whether they have similarly accepted the need for restraint in their individual claims on national income because, firstly, there is probably a great deal more diversity within that group than there is in the wage earning population and, secondly, there is no centralised system under which a generally agreed policy could be either put in place or subsequently monitored.

My attention has been drawn to the article in the National Times. It cites research on salaries in 150 top management jobs by the consulting firm of Cullen, Egan and Dell which shows that senior management salaries have increased by almost 12 per cent in the 12 months up to 1 April. In that same period the increases in average weekly earnings were around 6 per cent and in award wages 6.6 per cent over the last calendar year. If that survey finding is reliable it is disturbing to learn that the managerial and executive employees, for want of a better term, have taken for themselves wage increases almost double that of wage earners in general. It is particularly disturbing when one recognises that it is from that group that the strongest and most sanctimonious exhortations to the rest of the work force are being made-exhortations on the rest of the work force that it must moderate its individual demands on national income. That survey at least shows that the people who are making those sanctimonious demands on exhortations are not following their own advice. The same article in the National Times cites the increases granted to directors' fees for some 20 leading Australian firms. There are some complications there because of changes in functions of directors, but increases in the 12-month period range from a bottom figure of minus 0.12 per cent to a top figure of some 80.7 per cent. I should add that the minus figure is certainly aberrant, being the only minus figure; and only four of the 20 or so firms have had increases in less than double figures in directors' fees.

I note that the survey by Cullen, Egan and Dell did not take into account any increases in superannuation. So it is possible that the total salary packages, to use the euphemism which has become popular in recent years, increased by even more than the direct remuneration figures show. All that being so, I think those comparisons are invidious and I would hope, and the Government would hope, that in the present climate, and particularly in view of the Australian Statistician's publication last week of the huge adverse movement in Australia's terms of trade that has taken place over the last 12 months and the consequential reduction in the national income, the managerial and executive class will practice what it preaches and moderate its demands on national income as well as exhort the work force in general.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Has the Government seen the extraordinary disclosure in documents released over the weekend by the United States Nautilus Pacific Research Institute that there were 381 naval related nuclear weapons accidents from 1965 to 1977 and the unbelievable statistic that the United States Navy had accidentally released nuclear weapons in 1965, 1968, 1969 and 1970? Is the Government concerned that these ships carrying nuclear weapons of the same Navy are visiting Australian ports with increasing frequency? If a nuclear weapon was accidentally released, say in Sydney Harbour, would we be able to cope with it? In the light of the Nautilus information, will the Government be following up the 1981 United States recommendation to conduct joint simulated nuclear weapons accidents under realistic conditions in Australian ports and Australian airfields?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have indicated on previous occasions that the Australian Government is satisfied that safety procedures taken on board visiting warships effectively preclude the possibility of nuclear weapon detonation. Given the construction and safety features of a modern warship, we believe that the spread of radiation outside a vessel by conventional explosion or fire is almost equally as remote. The United States Navy has acknowledged that during the period 1965-85-a 20-year period-it experienced 630 accidents or incidents involving nuclear weapons. There is no evidence, however--
—That is a great safety record, isn't it?

—Just hear me out, Senator. There is no evidence that any of these mishaps has resulted in an explosion or a leak of radioactive material. The reason for the high number of accidents or incidents results from the United States Navy's very stringent system of reporting all mishaps, however minor, involving nuclear weapons, their components and even simulated nuclear weapons involved in training. The only serious incidents appear to have been losses of weapons while warships were at sea. One of these resulted from the loss of a nuclear armed fighter aircraft in the Western Pacific in 1965. At least one other may have been due to the loss of the submarine USS Scorpion in 1968.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is responsible for emergency planning for, and control of, responses to possible nuclear accidents in Australian harbours and has its own national procedures. This planning is undertaken, as I have indicated in response to other questions, particularly from Senator Vallentine recently, by State and Territory governments in consultation with Federal Government agencies. In the unlikely event of an accident the Australian Government would expect the United States to provide the maximum assistance feasible in the circumstances. Australia receives reports of United States nuclear weapons accident exercises and has sent observers to them. The issue of nuclear weapons accidents at Australian airports, which was one part of Senator Chipp's question, does not arise. United States B52 aircraft undertaking low level navigation training and maritime surveillance which transit Australia are, as I have said a dozen times on behalf of the Minister for Defence, unarmed and carry no bombs.

In regard to the last part of Senator Chipp's question-whether the Government will be following up the 1981 United States recommendation to conduct joint simulated nuclear weapon accidents under realistic conditions in Australian ports and Australian airfields-we do, as I say, send observers to the United States exercises. I will refer that part of Senator Chipp's question specifically to the Minister and seek a further detailed response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The Minister, in answer to my original question, said that the Australian Government `is satisfied with the safety requirements of United States warships'. I take it from that that this Government is satisfied that the record of 630 nuclear accidents in 20 years is satisfactory?

—I remind Senator Chipp of what exactly I did say. I said that we are satisfied that safety procedures taken on board visiting warships effectively preclude the possibility of nuclear weapon detonation. None of the incidents to which I referred, or to which Senator Chipp referred, involved detonation or anything remotely like it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. In view of the undertaking given this weekend by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Primary Industry that an investigation will take place to find out whether Australian banks are charging higher interest rates to farmers than other members of the community, will the Minister outline the scope of the inquiries that are to take place? Further, is there any evidence available that banks have been dealing in a fair manner with the public at large since they were allowed to lift the ceiling on new home loan interest rates? If not, is there any chance of the Government broadening the inquiry to take that into account?

—I personally am not aware of any definitive or authoritative evidence on this question of whether the banks are charging excessive rates to farmers. I have heard directly some anecdotal evidence which shows that the rates being charged are substantially higher than those charged to business borrowers in general. Even after allowing for the possibility of some premium being charged for additional risk, they do seem to be a bit high. But that evidence is anecdotal. The question was addressed in general terms in Mr Kerin's economic and rural policy statement on 15 April and subsequently, at the request of the Prime Minister's country task force, chaired by the honourable member for McMillan, Mr Cunningham, Mr Kerin met with senior executives of a number of banks on 16 May and is preparing to report to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer on the outcome of those discussions. The issues raised at that meeting included, among other things, banks' overall lending margins, the alleged imposition of penalty interest rates on rural borrowers, the level of administration and other bank charges, the criteria used in assessing applications for loans and the treatment of farmers in financial difficulty. The Prime Minister will consider that report from Mr Kerin and will follow up any aspects raised at his meeting with a number of farmers last Saturday which have not adequately been resolved in discussions so far.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government and follows the question to the Minister for Finance from Senator Messner about the possible reconsideration of the fringe benefits tax and its application to the farming community. I draw the attention of the Leader of the Government to the Minister for Finance's lack of knowledge about the matter. In light of the fact that the fringe benefits tax is to be dealt with in the Senate today and in light of the Prime Minister's statement to the farmers at Canowindra on the weekend that he, the Prime Minister, had not realised the extent of the problems for some farmers and would have a look at the matter and become informed of the factual situation, I ask the Minister: Is the Government going to reconsider the matter, or was the Prime Minister simply duchessing the farmers at Canowindra to get himself past an awkward meeting?

—First of all, it was not an awkward meeting. I am not familiar with the precise matters which were discussed in respect of the fringe benefits tax. I think it would be wrong to assume that any further consideration of the fringe benefits tax, if there was one, would have any bearing on the passage of this legislation as far as the Government was concerned. I will try to obtain a more detailed answer from the Prime Minister and will give it to Senator Chaney as soon as possible.

—I have a supplementary question. In view of the fact that we are to debate this legislation this afternoon, I ask the Leader of the Government whether he will seek to get a reply for the Senate before we resume that debate.
—Yes.

—Has the Minister for Education and Minister assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women seen Press reports concerning the expiry of exemptions under the Sex Discrimination Act for legislation limiting the weight of goods women are expected to lift in their employment? Will the Minister comment on statements made by the Shop Distributive and Allied Employees Association that from 1 August, unless the Sex Discrimination Act is amended, women shop assistants and junior males will no longer be covered by legislation limiting the weight of goods they are expected to lift?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the matters raised by the letter of the Shop Distributive and Allied Employees Association concerning the effect of the Sex Discrimination Act on the weight of goods women are expected to lift. The Government is concerned about the issues raised by the SDA and has taken a number of steps to meet these concerns. Our basic position is that the Sex Discrimination Act should not adversely affect the working conditions of women. Existing weight limits applying to juniors and women provide no protection for adult men and may not provide wholly adequate protection for women.

ANSWER.PARA: The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission is preparing a discussion paper on manual handling, including recommendations in relation to existing provisions which differentiate on sex and age, and a draft code of practice on manual handling. In the meantime, the Government recognises that a limited extension for specified State legislation intended to protect women in employment is justified. Such an extension would allow time for the State governments to complete their reviews of discriminatory legislation, for a conference on restrictive legislation to be held, and for any necessary changes to the State Acts and regulations to be made. The conference on restrictive legislation will be a forum to gain broad agreement on a firm timetable for implementation of the necessary changes to legislation, regulations and awards. Occupational health and safety concerns, such as those raised in the letter of the SDA, will be fully addressed.

The Prime Minister has recently written to the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions advising him that the Government supports an extension of the exemption for 12 months for specified State legislation. Letters have also been sent to State Premiers and the Chief Minister seeking their urgent advice on protective employment legislation which they believe merits preservation.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON PRICES AND INCOMES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Minister agree with the Treasurer's description of the now adjourned Advisory Committee on Prices and Incomes economic conference as the most comprehensive discussion of issues since the summit of 1983? If so, why has such an important meeting now been relegated until after the Prime Minister's address and after the result of the national wage case is known; in other words, after the major economic decisions have been taken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reasons are set out quite clearly, I think, in the Prime Minister's Press statement which Senator Parer may not have had a chance to read. I do not intend to bore the Senate by reading all of it, but I will pick out some of the highlights. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: The most recent economic statistics, notably the March quarter; National Accounts and the ABS Survey of Investment Intentions graphically highlight the magnitude of the economic task before Australia.
While no major change in direction is required the statistics provide further confirmation of the need for some modification to our already successful policy . . .
The more substantive part reads:

In the Government's view discussions at ACPI will be most fruitful if both the outcome of the NWC and the details of proposed modifications to the Government's policy stance are known to participants in advance.
This view is also now shared by representatives of business and the ACTU

The two important things which have happened since the Treasurer made the statement were, firstly, that the quarterly national accounts figures were published. Although history shows that frequently those figures are subject to very substantial revision, they are certainly cause for concern. Most importantly, the outcome of the national wage case is not known now and informed opinion is that it will not be known for several weeks. There was little point in holding that tripartite meeting until the outcome of that case was known.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: OVERSEAS ACTORS: EASING OF WORK RESTRICTIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. Is the Minister aware of extensive concern among Australian actors about Federal Government plans to ease restrictions to allow more overseas actors-many of somewhat doubtful artistic merit-to work in this country? Will the Minister convey this concern to her colleague Mr Cohen and recommend that early consultation is held with Actors Equity to ensure that Australian actors' interests are fully protected and overseas artists' entry is appropriately controlled, so that only artists of exceptional quality enter on the same basis which has been successfully operating for many years?
—I will be happy to convey those sentiments to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. I must say that I endorse the sentiments that Senator Reynolds expressed in her question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education. I remind the Minister that on Friday, 30 May she was asked a question by Senator Reid about whether consideration had been given to the transfer of the Australian Capital Territory Apprenticeship Board to the Department of Territories. I remind the Minister that in her answer she said that consideration has been given to the transfer and, further, that the matter has not yet been finalised. I ask: Was the Minister telling the truth to the Senate?
—I have nothing further to add.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister aware that the transfer which she said was not yet complete was completely by way of the Seat of Government Administration (Amendment) Ordinance 1986, dated 10 April? Will the Minister confirm that she has misled the Senate, albeit unwittingly?

—When I was asked a question by Senator Reid the other day, I recalled that I had accepted advice from my Department that the transfer should go ahead. I could not recall whether the machinery has been set in progress for the matter to go ahead. If Senator Baume has been able to establish that it has, that is quite useful. But he is certainly dramatising the fact that there is a time lapse between a Minister agreeing to a course of action and that course of action being carried out.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and it relates to an advertisement placed by the establishment Jimmy's on the Mall on the front page of last Saturday's Courier-Mail in which it was stated that in August a sushi chef would be arriving from Japan. Has a chef from Japan been given a visa to enter Australia and work at Jimmy's on the Mall and, if so, what are the details of his visa? Has the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs made any inquiry of the relevant union or unions, either direct or through the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, about the possible employment of a Japanese chef at this or other locations in Brisbane? —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has informed me that an employer nomination for a sushi chef for Jimmy's on the Mall was approved by the Brisbane office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs on 13 May last. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON ANIMAL WELFARE: CHAIRMANSHIP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Georges in his capacity as Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare. Senator Georges will recall from the trip on which I accompanied him through rural Queensland the concern and fears felt by primary producers about the Animal Welfare Committee. Can he inform the Senate and primary producers whether he is still the Chairman of that Committee or does he intend to stand down during his suspension from the Australian Labor Party? If so, will he return as Chairman of the Committee after he has done his three months in the sin bin?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I could, I would pass that question swiftly to Senator Cooney. Unfortunately that is not possible. The chairmanship of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare has been a matter of discussion. On my suspension from the Australian Labor Party I took the view that, having been relieved of all other positions in the Party, my position on both the Animal Welfare Committee and the Public Accounts Committee was by virtue of my position in the Party. As far as chairmanship of the Animal Welfare Committee is concerned, I approached Senator Cooney and he recoiled in horror at the suggestion that he should chair that Committee. The other two members of the Committee have taken the view that I should remain. Therefore, the rural interest can speculate a little further. I suggest that they do not start cheering. I have received many letters requesting me to remain as Chairman of the Committee, but I have not received one from the National Farmers Federation.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the matter of the sin bin, yes, I am in the sin bin. It is a different type of sin bin. I have to behave myself while I am in the sin bin otherwise I will not be allowed to return to the game.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, concerns the Government's taxation strategy. Has the Government's attention been drawn to reports that the Catholic Church in South Australia has expressed support for the Government's taxation strategy? Can the Government inform the Senate of the nature of that support?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had my differences with the Catholic Church over a few issues although, to get the record straight, I have never been a member. Most people seem to think I have been a member.

ANSWER.PARA: My attention has been drawn to this issue and to the statement by the Director of the South Australian Catholic Family Welfare Bureau, Mr Joseph O'Neill, who issued a telex supporting the Government's tax reform package, although I should add for complete accuracy that he was somewhat critical of our not having gone further than we did in some areas. Although I have had differences with the Catholic Church and its agencies from time to time I always thought it could be relied on on income distribution questions to do what I and the Government would regard as the morally correct thing. In this case as in most cases it has not let me down in that judgment. It is obvious, of course, that the Opposition does not agree with the moral judgments made on the tax reform package and on income distribution questions by this agency of the Catholic Church.

Senator Elstob also asked me about the Government's strategy on tax reform. It is basically to broaden the income tax base in order to reduce marginal tax rates by introducing a fairer system which eliminates an assortment of rorts which have been getting worse as time goes by and which, if allowed to continue unchecked, would have massively eroded the income tax base and consequentially, would have required higher and not lower marginal and average tax rates.

The Government has addressed that issue of broadening the income tax base in a variety of ways, but the principal way in which it has pursued that objective is by legislating in a way that encourages and provides incentives for employees to be paid in cash and not in kind; that is, an employee should receive wages instead of subscriptions to the Melbourne Club, school fees being paid at Geelong Grammar for his children, or overseas family travel and that assortment of so-called fringe benefits that progressively had been quantitative and more important over time and had provided a substantially eroded income tax base, to the detriment of the decent, administrable and fair system and to the disadvantage of the great bulk of taxpayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware that the rate of youth unemployment is now nearly 23 per cent, which is no better than it was when the Australian Labor Party came to power in March 1983 and which is 6 per cent higher than the average of the Fraser years? Is the Minister aware that the average duration of unemployment among full time workers has risen to 49 weeks in March of this year, compared with 35 weeks when Labor came to office? Given these facts, will the Government abandon the fringe benefits tax which will be both inflationary and job destroying and the accord which has helped to give Australia unacceptably high inflation, undermined our international competitiveness, created record real interest rates and contributed to an appalling balance of payments situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I used to be fairly impressed with Senator Hill. He has emerged as a very amateurish sort of ideologue by this question. I did hear all his mini statistics, if I might call them that. It is not true that youth unemployment is at as high a rate as it was at the end of the Fraser years. I do not know what the honourable senator is purporting to illustrate, but there is not much point in saying that the unemployment rate is 6 per cent higher than the average for the Fraser years. We have never said that unemployment for either young or older people was high in the earlier years of the Fraser Government; it just got worse and worse as time went on. That was the problem. That was the matter to which we have drawn attention and to which we have objected. It is silly to strike an average for the purposes of making a pedantic little heuristic point in the Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator talked about the duration of unemployment rising to 49 weeks amongst people who are unemployed for a longer time-the sort of hard core unemployed, as they are sometimes called. I was not familiar with that statistic. I will certainly have that matter examined and will be able to make some comment on it in due course. I think the point which probably sticks in the honourable senator's craw is that whatever he wants to say about these figures, which are sort of sub-figures of a bigger scene, under this Government the unemployment situation in this country has been greatly improved for all workers, including younger workers. The participation rates are at a record high level.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the expense of the deficit.

—The Archer solution. That is very interesting. The employment record of this Government is satisfactory. We cannot say that it is anything to be complacent about, but certainly, in terms of the numbers of jobs that have been created and so on, and the reduction in the levels of unemployment, the Government has made more progress than it promised it would do; and the community is fairly satisfied with that, even if Senator Hill is not.

ANSWER.PARA: I come to the absurd point of the honourable senator's question. He went, if a I might say so, from the less than sublime to the absolutely ridiculous when he asked whether the Government would abandon the fringe benefits tax and the accord as a solution to the problem which he tried to establish with those rather shonky little figures that he produced. The answer to both those questions is no. If the honourable senator's Party came into government, I have no doubt that it would do both. I also have no doubt that unemployment would rise, that inflation would rise, that we would be back to the old wage spiral which characterised the last shaky years of the Fraser Government, and that we would have five years of industrial warfare, as the honourable senator's lawyer leader proclaims. I think all those things will happen. I want the honourable senator's Party to try that some day, if it ever gets the opportunity. It is not going to be us.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Has the attention of the Minister been drawn to a petition on petrol prices being circulated in country areas of South Australia? If so, does the Minister accept the petition's claim that rural petrol users are subsidising those in the cities? Has the Minister anything further to add to his answer to my question on country petrol prices on 14 April?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have explained on previous occasions why it is that petrol prices tend to be higher in country areas as compared with the metropolitan scene-because of the higher cost of supply to consumers in country areas, the higher wholesaling and retailing costs associated with the smaller sales volumes in those areas and also the reduced competitive situation which means that country and regional areas tend not to get the benefit of discounting.
—And the cost of freighting it there.

—I have said that. I referred to the higher costs of supply, which, I think the honourable senator would appreciate, include the cost of freight. It is still the case that the Commonwealth does give a very substantial freight subsidy-above a level of 5.2c per litre-for any freight costs incurred beyond that particular maximum. We are not aware of any cross-subsidies that are inherent in the pricing structure for petroleum products-that is to say, higher margins being received by the companies for country sales as a matter of course-although, from time to time, no doubt those margins do tend to be a little higher for the reasons that I have already spelt out.

ANSWER.PARA: I have indicated also on previous occasions that any attempt to regulate the scene in the rural and regional areas in order to try to equalise the situation to a greater degree than exists at the moment is destined to failure because of the pressures to which I have referred and that there would be unnecessary and unhappy distortions introduced into petrol marketing were a greater degree of uniformity of pricing to be insisted upon. In any event, that is something that the Commonwealth cannot effectively do with its present limited constitutional powers. It must be a matter for the States.

The sum total of all that is that the Australian Democrats' petition that is being circulated that I have seen Press reports about, although I have not seen the terms of it, really is quite misconceived insofar as it expressly or impliedly suggests that there is any blame to be borne by governments, or anyone else for that matter, for the differential in pricing which does exist and which is undoubtedly a source of grievance and burden to country people. But regrettably that is not something that anyone can really do anything about.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. As it appears from newspaper reports, Mr Kerin was a reluctant participant in the weekend farm public relations exercise because `it sets a precedent and raises expectations that cannot be met'. Does the Minister agree with the suggestion at that meeting that farmers' employees' accommodation may be exempted from fringe benefits tax or was the excursion just what it was purported to be-a public relations exercise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —If any farmer wants to gain exemption from fringe benefits tax, like every other employer, he can do it by the simple expedient of charging the market rental and, in this case, increasing the wages to cover it. But that is no problem. What I really want to take up is Senator Brownhill's reference to raising expectations which cannot be met. That is a perfect description of what the Leader of the Opposition has been doing to the farmers and to just about every other group in the community that one can think of. Two weeks ago the shadow Ministry's rural policy-which Senator Chaney later said was a Clayton's policy and not a policy at all because it was something that had no status and had not been endorsed; but anyway for the present purposes I will call the Opposition's rural policy-was leaked. It showed promises totalling more than $500m in additional expenditure for the agricultural sector alone. Of course, when I referred to that in the Senate, Senator Chaney said `But that is not the Opposition's policy at all; that is just a draft', implying that the Opposition is not committed to anything that is in it.

ANSWER.PARA: I invited Senator Chaney then and I invite him again and also Mr Sinclair, Mr Hunt and Mr Howard, to specify which of the specific items in that shopping list of political goodies which totals more than $500m, the Opposition is repudiating and which the Opposition is just putting out not because it intends to do anything about it but because it is in the business of raising expectations not only which cannot be met but which it has absolutely no intention of attempting to meet.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. How many youth access centres have been launched in Commonwealth Employment Service offices and what is the role of those centres? Can the Minister indicate how many young people are making use of youth access centres?

—I am advised that some 34 youth access centres have been officially launched on a trial basis in CES offices and that a further three centres will be opened in the near future. The proposition was nationally launched by my colleague and good friend Mr Willis on 6 February last. The role of youth access centres is to provide young people with separate and specialised advice and counselling on careers and training opportunities, educational opportunities and income support options available to them, as well as access to employment services generally. Early indications are that the centres are receiving widespread support and usage. At the end of March 1986 some 14,000 clients had used the services of the 34 existing centres, many of which were opened only in early February. The note that I have on this subject might be somewhat dated. If the figures which I have given need revision, I will supply that information later to Senator Zakharov.
—Mr President, I ask the Minister to table the document from which he has quoted.
—Is the Minister prepared to table the document?
—Yes.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Since the time that His Honour Mr Justice Lionel Murphy stood down from the High Court of Australia nearly two years ago, how many of his staff have been retained? What work have they been doing? Have any of them been transferred to other duties? If so, what duties and from where are they being paid?
—I will refer that question to the Attorney-General and seek his response.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence and relates to his answer to my question on 17 April on the comprehensive test ban treaty and the strategic defence initiative. Has the Minister seen the report on the front page of the New York Times of 21 April 1986 which quoted senior officials at the Los Alamos National Laboratories in the United States of America as saying that, whereas six underground nuclear tests were usually required for developing a new weapon, new designs for the third generation of nuclear weapons and the strategic defence initiative could require 100 or 200 explosions? How does the Australian Government propose to press the Reagan Administration for a comprehensive test ban treaty in light of this commitment to continue with such a huge test program well into the next decade? Finally, can he tell the Senate how the Government reconciles its commitment to a comprehensive test ban treaty and its alleged influence with the United States Government with the comment made by Jenni Hewett in the Sydney Morning Herald on 31 May 1986 that `on issues like arms control and negotiating a comprehensive test ban, the United States politely listens to, and then ignores what Australia says'?

—As Senator Vallentine ought to know by now, disarmament matters are more properly addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It is in the capacity of representing him that I respond to her. I have seen the two media reports to which Senator Vallentine referred. As I indicated in my answer to her question on 17 April, there clearly is a difference between Australia and the United States on the question of a comprehensive test ban and in regard to the appropriate context in which such a treaty could be concluded. None of the points that have been raised by Senator Vallentine will prevent the Australian Government from presenting its views on a comprehensive test ban treaty to the United States as vigorously as possible. A team of Australian officials is in fact in Washington this week for arms control consultations which will cover this issue.
—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Senator Button.
—Order! It is Senator Walsh.

—The Minister will be aware of the report given wide publicity in the media on the day the Builders Labourers Federation was deregistered that $1.5m was withdrawn from the union's bank in Melbourne. I am reliably informed that assets of the BLF in New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory total approximately $10m. Will the Minister inform the Senate what steps the Government is taking to ensure that these funds are returned to the persons who were financial members of the union at the time the union was deregistered and not used by the members of the Executive of the BLF for their own benefit or to fund industrial disputes within other unions and within industry generally, to the detriment of the Australian work force and its employers?

—Senator Walters originally referred this question to Senator Button. If it had been 18 months or so earlier, she would have been correct in so doing. If her perceptions of the world are 18 months behind what is actually happening in the world, I suppose that puts her a long way in front of most of her colleagues. On the substance of the question, as I understand the situation-I will check it with Mr Willis-the Commonwealth Government has absolutely no power over the funds of the BLF in New South Wales or Victoria because there are State registered organisations there and the funds are held by the State organisations and, therefore, only the State governments are able to direct or influence what might happen to them. I also have a vague recollection of one or both of those State governments having made a statement that they would be watching the position. I believe that Mr Willis or some other responsible person in the Commonwealth Government has made a similar statement in regard to the Australian Capital Territory branch of the Builders Labourers Federation which is under Commonwealth control. I will check that out to see whether I am correct in believing that a statement was issued some time ago, and also get any additional information which is available.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health seen the article in the Age on 2 May 1986 headed `Australia and US neck-and-neck in race to develop unisex pill'? It describes the close contest between companies in Australia and the United States to produce a hormone called inhibin? As this contest centres on patents for the various stages of the research and could mean enormous financial gains to the country which wins, does the Minister agree with the assessment by Dr Neil Willets of Biotechnology Australia that Australia is in `a good patent position'? Can he say what is the current state of play in this research contest?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did read the article. The cloning of the hormone inhibin has been the aim of many research organisations in the world for a long time. In recent months the large United States company Genentech managed to clone pig inhibin. Soon after, Biotechnology Australia plus Prince Henry's Hospital, Monash University and St Vincent's Institute of Medical Research in Melbourne managed to clone inhibin from a bull. I suppose, as is well known, that as pigs are closer than bulls to human beings Genentech might be said to be ahead. In fact, that is not so; the hormones are almost identical. These hormones must now be tested and developed. I can assure any of my more athletic colleagues in the place that they need not rush out to look for inhibin as it will not be on the market for about 10 years. I suppose some of my colleagues might get in on the research into this drug in less time that that. What happens now is that the battle will go on between I suppose Genentech and Biotechnology Australia as to who can get the patent first and who can get the patent registered in most countries. As Senator Crowley said, Dr Willets has been working in this area for a long time. I suppose this fact is reflected in his language when he said to the Age:

ANSWER.PARA: We hope this will give us a good patent position . . . how it will in the end stack up against the Genentech patents remain to be seen.

Dr Willets has made the fairly sensible suggestion that it may be a good idea if Genentech and Biotechnology Australia combined their considerable research and development talents to introduce such a unisex pill which would be potentially of great advantage in a rapidly overpopulated world. Inhibin, in fact, inhibits the production of ova in females and spermatozoa in males and seems to do so without suppressing libido. I know many people in the world would like to be in a position to use such substances, but as I said, it will take about 10 years, so they need not join the queue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In light of comments made today by the Minister for Finance referring to the improper raising of expectations by an Opposition draft policy document, does the Government agree that the Priority One: Young Australia program and in particular the Australian traineeship scheme has improperly raised the expectation of young Australians given that the target of 10,000 traineeships will not be reached? In fact on the mainland there are only just over 1,000 traineeships in place with only 52 in the private sector. Given the announcement in September 1985 of 500 traineeships with Ansett Airlines of Australia, none of which are in place nine months later, will the Minister tell the Senate what has gone wrong and whether the Government agrees that this announcement unfairly raised the expectations of young Australians?

—I am not responsible in any way for what Ansett might have said at one stage or another. People can draw their own conclusions about whether anticipations were raised or not. The honourable senator asked of me as Minister whether the Priority One program improperly raised expectations. Certainly, the Government is disappointed with the progress of the Priority One traineeships. However, we are working away at them and I think we will get better results than are currently expected. I hope for that.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today during Question Time Senator Chaney asked me a question about the fringe benefits tax and statements made by the Prime Minister. I can perhaps advance the information on this matter a little further by saying that the Prime Minister in a Press conference today was asked about this matter. I quote from the transcript of that Press conference. The Prime Minister said:

ANSWER.PARA: Well I had raised with me specifically the question of the impact of the fringe benefits tax for employees. I just want to look at that and get some information about the degree of impact and Peter knows I've not promised anything on that. I just want to inform myself on the dimension of it. They-
that is, the farmers-

are making the point that if they've got no income they're not paying any tax otherwise, and yet get hit with this tax. They regard that as an anomaly and a problem. I certainly want to have a look at that. They have certainly placed some stress on that.

DEBATE.TITLE: VISIT TO JAPAN, CHINA AND THE PHILIPPINES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Text of Statement by Prime Minister

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Having recently visited all three countries discussed in the statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-that is, China, Japan and the Philippines-I would agree with the importance of visits to them by an Australian Prime Minister. At the outset, I would like to mention briefly the extraordinary nature of the presentation of business in this place in that this statement, which is a ministerial statement by no less a person than the Prime Minister, has been brought down as a paper. There is an increasing tendency on the part of the Government to deal with matters in this way and I think that this is regrettable. This statement, which is of considerable importance sets out the Prime Minister's impression of perhaps three of the most important countries with which we have to deal. It ought to be debated reasonably and properly and should not be subject to the very considerable constraints which are applied in regard to debate on papers. I just bring that to the Government's attention.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal with the Philippines first. I believe that Australia has a major responsibility to assist the Aquino Government through the post-Marcos stage. This will not be easy. The levels of support for the communist New People's Army in many regions of the Philippines represent a major problem. As always, of course, the communist insurgent movement thrives on basic economic deprivation of the people. We see here a lesson which apparently the Western world has found itself incapable of learning over a period of 40 years, having put forward fallacious ideas like domino theories and things of that kind. Nations are not dominoes to fall over one after another; they are groups and assemblies of human beings and they will respond to events as human beings normally will. It is a fact that if people are grossly suppressed by a governing clique to the extent of serious economic deprivation of those people, they will look for an alternative. They looked for an alternative in China and Indo-China and we lost those countries because of our failure to perceive that. Too often an alliance between the traditionally land rich families and the military forces in the Philippines has suppressed the villagers, the people of the barrios, into a state of virtual serfdom to these vested interests.

If that is considered an overstatement, let us look back at the publicity during the persecution of Father Brian Gore by the Philippines military. The situation in the Philippines is quite as bad as it was in the years before the communist takeover in China and in those other countries we have lost. The way to reduce and remove the influence of the New People's Army is to address those problems. If the Australian Government can persuade Mrs Aquino to embark on a genuine program of land reform and removal of the regional power of the military units and can assist her materially in these things, I believe we will be doing something of vast importance, but it will not happen if the rest of the world just stands by and watches. I suspect that those problems may well be too big for Mrs Aquino to tackle alone, and that is not intended as a criticism of her.

It is apparent from what the Prime Minister said in his statement about the Philippines that he sees some of these problems. The 50 per cent increase in our aid and the visit of an aid team to see what we can do further are good steps in the right direction. Australians, on the whole, are popular in the Philippines. We have a great opportunity there in that most Filipinos speak English. Maybe Australians should be looking at a far larger movement of people as advisers and project officers to the Philippines to assist this process of social and economic reform, something more or less along the lines of the Peace Corps projects of the past; and I particularly think of the Australian Volunteers Abroad program. This is an opportunity perhaps for some of our unemployed young people who are qualified as teachers and other things to carry out social revolution, in the best sense of the word, in a part of Asia which will be of vital importance to us in the future. I commend that possibility. There is a need for people-not just for money to be thrown at things with some sense of dedication and purpose to go there. I think that would be of enormous value.

I hope that we have learnt from China and Japan. On page 2 of the Prime Minister's statement he pointed to the importance of tourism between Australia and Japan. That is fine, but will he see to it that the long-standing shortage of passenger aircraft between the two countries is remedied so that people who want to go backwards and forwards between Australia and Japan will not be hampered by artificial constraints of that kind? The Prime Minister might also learn from the Japanese attitude towards business and national objectives. The Japanese know that it is a tough, competitive world. They are now making a major and courageous advance into new technology, with a group of regional centres they call technopolies, which will throw Japan directly into the late twentieth century with the most wide ranging set of new proposals I have seen. This is being done by the Japanese Government providing leadership and finance. The Japanese Government realises, as this Government does not, that government has the responsibility to be a cutting edge, to be a leader in this area of new technology.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief statement on the same subject.
—Leave is granted, but I think it would be appropriate if statements were limited to five minutes, as Senator Mason limited his statement.

—I will limit my contribution to five minutes. I welcome the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and I will confine my remarks to the People's Republic of China. Gough Whitlam said in his book The Whitlam Government 1972-1975 that the essence of a sound foreign policy was the intelligent anticipation of change. That statement was used again recently by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) when he made a foreign policy statement to the Parliament. Whitlam gave a number of examples in his book of the intelligent anticipation of change, but the most striking example was that of China. Whitlam advocated recognition of the People's Republic of China when the Australian Labor Party was in opposition. He put the policy into effect when we won government and the Chinese have not forgotten that our policy was not popular in Australia at the time. The then Prime Minister McMahon and other conservatives in Australia ridiculed Mr Whitlam and the ALP. In fact, it was President Nixon who pulled the rug out from under McMahon and the tories. Kissinger was in Beijing at the same time as Gough Whitlam, Mick Young and the Australian Labor Party delegation were there in 1972.

SPEECH.PARA: That United States action assisted Whitlam and the Labor Party to win government. It removed foreign policy as an election issue. I believe it gave the Labor Party an issue with which to run during the campaign. Whitlam also gave other examples of the intelligent anticipation of change-Papua New Guinea and southern Africa-and history has also proved that the policies were correct in that regard. But our policies in regard to China and our relationship with China have had a lasting effect. They have led to the excellent relations that exist between Australia and China today. The Prime Minister said in his statement:

In opening our discussions Premier Zhao Ziyang said that China attached very great significance to building the relationship with Australia and to realising the full potential of our relationship. China's seriousness about this, which my Government fully reciprocates, was reflected in the exceptional opportunities provided for intensive discussions throughout the visit.

The Prime Minister then listed the people to whom he was able to speak. He had access to the Chinese leadership at all levels. This morning I received another example of the building of the relationship between Australia and China. During the recent visit by a delegation from the National People's Congress, discussions were held between that delegation and the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, of which I am Chairman. Members of the Chinese delegation were keen for our Committee to exchange views with the Foreign Affairs Committee of the National People's Congress and have invited a delegation from the Committee to visit China and possibly take part in the National Day celebrations. I am hopeful that some Committee members can use their travel allowance and accept the invitation.

When the Chinese delegation visited Canberra recently, it informed me that the parliamentary delegation, led by the President, Senator Douglas McClelland, and which also included Senator Jones, Senator Sheil and Senator Mason, was one of the best parliamentary delegations ever to visit China from any country. During the Prime Minister's visit a number of priorities were discussed, including the economic modernisation that is taking place in China today and how important it is that these new opportunities will be available to Australia.
