DEBATE.TITLE: PROMPT PAYMENT OF COMMONWEALTH ACCOUNTS BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to the payment of commercial accounts payable by the Commonwealth or by an authority of the Commonwealth.
Bill presented by Senator Archer, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Today I present a private member's Bill for an Act relating to the payment of commercial accounts payable by the Commonwealth or by an authority of the Commonwealth, of which the short title will be Prompt Payment of Commonwealth Accounts Act 1986. I am pleased to say that the Opposition parties have agreed to support me on this Bill.

This Bill has become necessary because governments at all levels now occupy such an important place in the market that the business community, particularly small business, is providing many services to government. This is highlighted by the fact that in 1950 governments of Australia consumed 15 per cent of gross domestic product whereas today the figure is 45 per cent. These figures indicate the extent to which government has increased its financial dealings with Australian business.

In difficult economic conditions, prompt payment of accounts is crucial to maintaining viability of business. Any small businessman would tell us how important the cash flow is to the success, and often survival, of his business. When cash flows are interrupted by delays from payment of government accounts, other creditors are not sympathetic. The situation becomes both serious and ludicrous when the creditor is that same government which is slow to pay. As government continues to expand its activities into the community with such examples as Medicare and the supply of medicines, the ever-increasing sectors of business and professions are becoming substantially reliant for their income on government payments. It is essential to guarantee that they are paid promptly.

The coalition does not believe that the business sector should be involved in providing an extravagant government with interest-free loans by way of extended terms of credit. There is mounting evidence, as this Government gets further into the financial mess of its own creation, coming from business, and particularly the small business sector, of ever-increasing delays in payment of government debts to its creditors therefore causing business to become the unpaid bankers to government.

Government is very demanding of the taxpayers and its debtors, as anyone who has had dealings with the Australian Taxation Office, Australia Post, Telecom Australia or the Australian Customs Service will tell you. Not only does it require payment immediately but it invokes heavy statutory penalties in pursuing outstanding amounts. To take but one example, the Commissioner of Taxation, the Government's principal credit manager, is now equipped with a massive armoury of penalties for late payment of even a few days. He can add 20 per cent interest to both the outstanding amount and the penalty. Because of this I, on behalf of the Opposition parties, have prepared this legislation as a major step in overcoming this present unacceptable situation.

In stark contrast, the Federal Government has a well-deserved reputation as an and extraordinary tardy payer of its outstanding accounts. Just how bad this situation has become is apparent from the hundreds of representations made to my office since I gave notice in early 1985 of my intention to introduce a Bill to provide for the prompt payment of commercial accounts by the Commonwealth and its statutory authorities. The reasons are numerous and include inefficiency and a sometimes callous disregard by public servants of the cash flow problems of Australian business. No doubt one of the principal reasons is the dramatic overspending inherent in Keating Budgets which has increased the Federal Government's indebtedness by $20,000m and has seen interest charges to the Commonwealth double to almost $7,000m and in that process move from the fifth highest to the second highest direct expenditure item in the Budget. Clearly there is now good reason for the Government to wish to gain interest free credit from its creditors.

The fact that a private member has to introduce a Bill to provide for prompt payment of commercial accounts by the Government and its statutory authorities is an indictment of this Government. Despite its rhetoric of concern for the problems facing the business community this Government, which is daily faced with the evidence of hardship suffered by honest, hard-working men and women imposed by the very late payment of moneys owed to them by the Federal Government, has done nothing to correct this situation. For this reason, we in the Opposition have taken the initiative to develop a practical and effective solution.

Faced with a similar problem, but one of a far larger scale, President Reagan introduced in 1982, and subsequently received Congressional support for, legislation to ensure the prompt payment of United States federal agencies commercial accounts. The Prompt Payment Act, Public Law 97-117, which came into force in 1983, requires federal agencies to pay their bills on time or pay interest penalties on late payments. The executive office of the President, the Office of Management and Budget, reports that prior to the passage of the Act as much as 30 per cent of government bills were paid late. In fact, in 1983 and 1984 financial years, federal agencies made more than 99 per cent of their payments for goods and services on time; that is, of course, after the introduction of that legislation. Two-thirds of the remaining figure is the responsibility of the United States Defence Department which, because of the special nature of its procurement processes, is a chronically late payer. The United States legislation was based on these premises: It would result in timely payment; better business relationships with suppliers; improved competition for federal acquisitions; and reduced cost to government. I think that particular statement is worth repeating: Reduced cost to government. Quite clearly, business that has the experience of being required to wait a long time for its money makes adjustments in the prices that it is prepared to offer to government and the taxpayer becomes the final person to pay in that regard.

I now turn to the individual clauses in this Bill. Briefly, the Bill provides for the Government to pay its commercial accounts on the 25th of the month following invoice or pay interest on the amounts outstanding. Clause 1 deals with the short title of the Bill and clause 2 covers the interpretation of terms used. This clearly defines those bodies which are covered under this legislation and provides a clear definition of a commercial account, due date and enactment, et cetera. Clause 3 deals with the extension of the Act to external Territories. This Bill is to apply to all Commonwealth of Australia departments, statutory authorities and administrations in the external Territories. Clause 4 covers the duty of the Commonwealth to pay each commercial account that falls due in one month on or before the 25th of the next following month. This will allow those taxpayers owed money to be paid and receive any moneys prior to the end of the month.

Clause 5 enacts the payment of interest by the Commonwealth on overdue accounts. This clause becomes effective when the Commonwealth fails to pay a commercial account on or before the due date in respect of that account. If this occurs, the Commonwealth is liable, by virtue of this Act, to pay in addition to the amount due, interest on the amount so due, whether it is all or part of the original account. The rate of interest that will be charged is that rate at the time ordinarily charged by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia in respect of loans in excess of $100,000. The point I make there is that the Government is generally able to borrow money at a lower rate than that particular cost. But of course the businessman-creditor is not able to borrow money at a cheaper rate than that and under these arrangements there will be no profit to the businessman; there will be a penalty to government that is tardy in paying its accounts. There will be no profit to the businessman, it will only offset the interest costs he is bound to incur as a result of having to borrow money to pay his other creditors when he is unpaid by government. All interest penalties will be paid at the same time as the account is paid.

Clause 5 (3) deals with litigation and arbitration and it clearly points out that where the Commonwealth or the Government chooses to contest a cost, a charge, levied upon it and there follows litigation, the interest will be payable by the Commonwealth on the arbitrated amount. If there is a settlement in favour of the business person concerned or the business concerned, that settlement will attract interest for the period of time that it has been outstanding from the date on which the amount was first claimed. This, of course, has another effect and that effect is to ensure that public servants and others do not use the course of litigation to delay payment deliberately because if they do so, and they are unsuccessful or even partially unsuccessful, they will have to pay interest on the amount so settled.
At this point I feel it is appropriate to quote from a letter I received from a small businessman in Queensland who has written to me concerning this Bill. He says:

On the subject of penalties for late payment, we feel that your proposed Act does not present a severe enough deterrent for the public servants. In addition, it is totally inconsistent when viewed in the light of the Income Assessment Act.
In other words, the rules of the tax man. He continues:
As an initial point, this Act demands payment of group tax payments by private industry employers by the 7th day of each month.
There he is comparing it with the 25th day recorded in this legislation. He goes on:

Some latitude then appears to be allowed on this requirement up to approximately the 16th day of each month after which the penalty applies. Penalties are then calculated at the rate of 20 per cent per annum.
He continues:
We therefore submit that requirement deemed necessary for private industry, should therefore form the basis of the minimum requirement necessary to apply to the public servants.

Clause 6 determines the date on which a commercial account falls due. This can occur when an agreement is reached by the provider of the goods and services with the Commonwealth and in such cases the account will become payable in accordance with the provisions of that agreement. In all other cases, the account will fall due for payment on the day on which a request, in writing, for payment of that amount is received by the Commonwealth from the provider of those goods or services. Clause 7 clearly indicates the actual time when payment is deemed to have been made. If an account is paid by prepaid post, the day on which a cheque or bill of exchange, et cetera, is posted to the person entitled to payment at the last known address is the date on which that account is deemed to have been paid, or, in any other case, on the day on which the amount or cheque or bill of exchange for the amount is delivered to the person or paid as directed by that person. This is certainly more positive than a statement in a recent government tender document which said that the payment is `deemed to have been made when the cheque has been drawn'. I would not like to have to be doing business in that regard and be told that I have been paid because my debtor has, in fact, drawn the cheque. This particular requirement in my legislation certainly clears up that position.

Clause 8 deals with the moneys to cover any interest penalties incurred by the Commonwealth in the late payment of its taxpayers accounts. Any additional amounts added to the original account for interest penalties are considered as part of the original account and therefore must be paid out of moneys appropriated by the Parliament to the relative department, authority or external Territory for the purpose. Authority is also given in this clause for any moneys appropriated by the Parliament for the purpose of the provision of goods or services to the Commonwealth authorities or external Territories to be deemed to be legally available for the payment of interest penalties incurred. This clause has the double effect of making this private member's Bill constitutional as it does not commit the Government to extra expenditure and placing the interest penalty firmly on the respective departmental budget. Late payers will consequently suffer reduced expenditure capacity in other areas. I am sure that may be just the incentive that many departments need to be more prompt in their payment to their creditors.

Clause 9 allows for the Commonwealth to receive discounts for prompt payment of its accounts. It will be the duty of the Commonwealth, in calling tenders for the provision of goods and services, to seek to obtain a discount for payment of commercial accounts related to the provision of those goods or services before the due dates in respect of those accounts. There are certain circumstances when the cost to a tenderer of short term financing of costly goods sold to government can substantially exceed the equivalent cost to government and must be included in the tendered price. Clearly the taxpayer should be protected from such additional cost incurred purely to accommodate a lazy public sector. It is not that long ago that a public servant advised a seminar that business should not make offers relating to better discounts for prompt payment as it was just too difficult for them to handle. Quite obviously that is a cost to the taxpayer and should not occur. Clause 10 is the transitional clause of this Bill. It provides that the Act apply to commercial accounts in respect of goods and services provided to the Commonwealth before or after the commencement of this Act, other than those accounts which have been paid in full including those commercial accounts that fall due for payment before, but not yet paid before, the commencement date of this Act.

I know that Government members will introduce all sorts of reasons for the defeat of this very important initiative for business, particularly small business. I am hopeful that the first Government speaker I see listed, the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), will be prepared to state the genuine case as it relates to the pharmacy industry which, as we all know, has been one of the major providers of interest free funds to the Government. I will be interested to hear his comments; nevertheless, I am expecting to hear such words as: `Well, governments run to strict budgets; clearly, they do pay on time; departments must be accountable for the public purse expenditure; there are strict processes to be adhered to when dealing with the taxpayers' money; all this is too hard to implement'. The Government has become too inflexible in its accounts paying process and it is time that it is forced to make allowance for the prompt payment of its accounts and not continue to offer excuses all the time. On many occasions approval for payment must be given by persons not connected with the realities of business or accounting. Conscientious clerical workers often are unable to receive approvals from paper-shy `other occupation' staff. An example given to me from members of the consulting engineering profession was that they often had very sympathetic accounts staff prepared to pay them but those same accounts staff could not get other engineers employed by government who did not like that sort of work to give the necessary approvals for payment of the account.

Some of the excuses used by government departments for late payment of their accounts would be comical if they were not true. The business sector has provided us with a list of the excuses. For instance, some departments claim they have never received the account. There is always the good old answer: `The cheque is in the mail'. Authorising officers are unfortunately on recreation leave, on sick leave, having a flexi-day off, et cetera, or just plain out. The excuse is given that the account is somewhere in the internal mail; the computer line is down; or the form was not endorsed or has an incorrect address upon it. If a business man rings up, the telephone is not answered or the person who answers says `This is not my problem, I am just passing through', or, `I am sure I paid that account'. There will be a lot of businessmen listening at the moment who have heard all these responses before. The classic was stated in this Parliament in 1985 when the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), in answer to a question from the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child) said that the problems `were due to the change over to the pharmpay system, to repetition strain injuries within that section of the Department and to some industrial troubles'. We are all aware of the problems of repetitive strain injury but that is no help to the people waiting for their payment; it is no excuse for government. The list goes on.

This financial year the Federal Government will spend approximately $69,000m or over $1,330m on average every week. Only part of this money goes to trade creditors. But the magnitude of actual money that is returned to the Government for every week's delay in payment of legitimate debts is still clearly substantial. This financial year the Government will have an anticipated deficit of $5,000m. However, government deficits can be manipulated by policy decisions to delay payment and a clear example of this is that the Government cannot at any one time tell anyone how much money it owes to the community by way of outstanding accounts. The cash accounting methods of the administrative government have never listed creditors. This Government expects the business community to do the same, and it is just not good enough.

I mentioned earlier in my speech that I had received many letters expressing concern about the late payment of government commercial accounts. I would like to cite a few of these cases so that those opposite can appreciate some of the problems facing those in the outside or real world. First, a small businessman whose debtors include many government departments was three weeks overdue in lodging his group taxation deductions of around $10,000, resulting in a fine of over $400 as a late payment penalty-a rate of nearly 70 per cent per annum. There are many people in the world who would call that usury. Secondly there is the case of a company which sells many products to government departments on 30 days payment terms and generally has to wait between 60 and 90 days for payment. Thirdly, there is the case of this businessman who writes:
I had to get a bank overdraft for the first time to cover my cash shortfall which, of course, means I pay interest due for the Government's bill.
Fourthly, another businessman writes:
At the moment we are right in the middle of tax payment time-and if we are one day late in paying that to the Government, we are liable to cop a 20 per cent penalty.
Fifthly, this businessman writes:

Of course, if a business such as mine were to reply to the Australian Taxation Office that we were unable to pay PAYE tax or other tax due because we were still awaiting payment for services rendered to the Commonwealth of Australia, the response would be completely unsympathetic and penalties and interest incurred. Is it not totally unjust that the Commonwealth can withhold payment for services rendered for excessive periods without incurring such interest penalties. It seems to me that our country has become rife with laws for `government' and laws for `the people'.

Sixthly, there is the case of a pharmacist who is owed $60,000 by the Department of Health-and this was put to me personally-but who had to borrow $20,000 to pay his income tax. Outstandings owed by the Government were, of course, included in his taxable income. So the debts that the Government owed him he was taxed on and then he had to borrow $20,000 to pay that tax.
Might I finish these examples with another quotation which I think clearly highlights the problems facing the commercial world:

Quite frankly, the whole process of getting payment out of the Government is a nightmare-one hesitates to accept work from the government departments for this reason. This experience is far from unique. The flow on implications in the commercial world of the Government's inability to pay contractors promptly is horrific and if allowed to continue will eventually cause many small businesses to go under, and the whole commercial process to grind to a halt. I have several clients who find it difficult to pay their outstanding accounts from this office, because, and I quote: `the Government is so slow at paying them'.

Only legislation will ensure that the Government's accounts are paid on time. This legislation which I present to the Parliament today will oblige governments-future governments as well as present governments-to pay their creditors on time and is vastly different from promises made on this matter by government leaders at various times which, of course, like other promises can be broken.

In Victoria, early in September 1985 Premier Cain issued an instruction that government agencies were to make sure their bills were paid on time. He did that in response to the fact that a small company was being liquidated because it could not survive; it was going broke for lack of cash flow. It was discovered that the Government of Victoria owed it $100,000, and Premier Cain was deeply embarrassed. But after saying that, it was reported in the Press in mid-October 1985 that the Department of Conservation, Forests and Lands had hundreds of accounts outstanding from 30 June 1985. So, five or six months after, these accounts were still outstanding and, in fact, those accounts outstanding included failure to pay registration fees for motor vehicles to the Government itself. In late November 1985 a small businessman in Victoria was reported as being owed $12,000 by the Victorian Government-in fact, by V/Line-for over seven months. He was owed $12,000 for seven months. How can anyone run a small business on that basis? So much for instructions and directions!

The only answer is legislation and, of course, we have the example of the American legislation being so effective. Literally months after its introduction suddenly the bureaucracy found that it could pay on time. In America 99 per cent of commercial accounts owed by the Federal Government are now paid on time. This Government should support this very worthwhile legislation to achieve this and not try to talk its way out of it. It is as simple as that. If government wants the business sector to pay it on time it is just as reasonable that government pay the business sector on time.

This Bill is not draconian. One correspondent suggested that the rules should be the same-the 7th of the month following. I stress that we are not on about promises, we are on about legislation that will oblige our Public Service to meet the obligation or pay the interest that will be incurred by the creditor at that time.

The situation is getting worse each year so it is very important that a decision is made on this serious problem now. Recent inquiries by the coalition parties have identified rising concern by those doing business with government of increasing delays in receiving payment. A New South Wales Chamber of Commerce survey showed last year that government departments take an average of 87 days to pay their accounts. In 1980 it was 63 days. This means that for every year we delay this legislation the length of time for governments to pay their accounts will be extended by five days. In less than three years it will be more than 100 days.

Just because a representative of a firm used by the Commonwealth Government in New York gives Australia a triple A credit rating and therefore considers it a very good risk does not mean that the Commonwealth has the right to take the same triple A rating as a licence to delay paying its outstanding accounts. Many government departments appear to do just that. Governments should not need to delay payment because of the reasons that can arise in commercial enterprises. Government runs to prepared budgets and unlike small business has unlimited credit and therefore need not make purchases if the funds are not available.

The honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) seemed very concerned as to how other members of business were treating each other. Let me say on behalf of those businesses that frequently decisions are taken in business to purchase a stock line or to enter into certain things that put unexpected pressure on a small business. Maybe the stock line does not sell; maybe another creditor does not come in; and occasionally small business is obliged to delay payment of its accounts because of those sorts of commercial realities. This should not apply to government. Government sets clear budgets, has access to the Reserve Bank of Australia for cash shortfalls and, of course, should not place the orders unless it has a clear indication that the money is available. Government is not in a commercial situation in that regard and it should not take the opportunity of the commercial sector of delaying payments of its accounts.

Only legislation demanding prompt payment or the payment of penalty can guarantee the fairness a democracy can expect. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 May, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Button, I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill is the main plank in the Government's package of measures to encourage research and development in industry.

Complementary legislation in the form of the Industry Research and Development Bill 1986 is currently before the Parliament. This provides for grants for research and development, to be directed to companies which cannot derive benefits from this proposed income tax concession. The grants scheme also allows for support to generic technologies and national interest projects. Thus, the two instruments represent a package of support measures for R&D in Australian industry.
The specific objectives of the proposed tax concession are:
to provide an incentive for greater levels of R&D in Australia;
to concentrate new R&D efforts in industry by greater business investment in, and responsibility for, R&D;
to provide positive support for R&D activities in industry, on the basis that significant benefits accrue both to industry and the wider community through enhanced competitiveness of industry;
to provide mechanisms for encouraging effective use of Australia's existing R&D expertise;
to encourage a capacity in industry to be aware of, and exploit, technological developments occurring in other countries.

These objectives are part of a broader set of objectives which seek to encourage, through the Government's industry and technology policies, the development in Australia of internationally competitive, export oriented, innovative industries.

Australian industry needs to improve its innovative skills and capability by increasing its investment in R&D, by better utilising the existing research infrastructure available in Australia and by developing a capacity for adoption of technology developed overseas.

It is only through Australian industry acquiring a ``technology culture'' that it and the wider Australian community can derive the significant economic and social benefits available from world-wide technological developments.
The Government's policies aim to assist Australian industry to be active participants in global developments in technology and re-industrialisation.

While recent figures have shown an encouraging increase in business sector R&D spending in Australia, this upturn has occurred only after a long period of dramatic decline. The level of expenditure remains well below what is necessary for the long term health of industry and well below that of our major trading partners.
R&D spending by Australian industry is estimated by the Australian Bureau of Statistics to be 0.3 per cent of GDP in 1984-85 compared with a median of 0.98 per cent for similar OECD economies.

The proposed tax concession will, at present company tax rates, reduce the after tax cost of performing R&D from 54 cents in the dollar to 31 cents in the dollar. Early indications are that this will result in a significant new effort in R&D.

Almost one thousand companies have so far indicated through registrations to the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board that they intend to make claims under the concession-the passage of this legislation should see still more companies making a commitment to R&D.

Of the companies which have so far given their estimates of R&D expenditure, an average real increase of over 30 per cent in 1985-86 relative to 1984-85 is expected, with a further 17 per cent increase in 1986-87 over 1985-86.

A particular feature of the proposed taxation concession is that it places decision-making concerning R&D in the hands of industry. Thus, it allows commercial considerations to determine the distribution and the level of R&D effort. Companies can also decide on the basis of their own strategies and resources how and where the R&D should be undertaken.

Provided R&D is undertaken in Australia, companies may choose to undertake their own R&D, to contract it out to other organisations or individuals in the private sector or to approved research institutions such as universities, the CSIRO, institutes of technology or colleges of advanced education.

The proposed concession is an increased incentive for industry to utilise the resources of public sector R&D institutions. This will give a greater practical, commercial orientation within these institutions.

This Bill will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 by providing income tax deductions of up to 150 per cent of expenditure (other than expenditure on buildings) incurred on research and development performed in Australia, during the period commencing 1 July 1985 and ending 30 June 1991. This proposal was announced on 29 May 1985.

To be eligible for the concession, a company must be registered with the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board or its replacement, the proposed Industry Research and Development Board.

The definition of eligible research and development activities was formulated after extensive consultation with industry, the scientific community and the Australian accounting profession. It is based on the definition of R&D used by the OECD and the Australian Bureau of Statistics. It closely resembles the definition used by the Canadian Government which operates a taxation concession scheme with similar features to this proposed concession.
Apart from presentational differences, the definition of research and development in the Bill is the same as that publicised when the Government announced its proposal to introduce this concession.

The central definition of research and development means activities of a systematic, investigative or experimental nature, involving innovation or technical risk undertaken for the purpose of acquiring new knowledge or for creating new or improved materials, products, processes or services. It thus encompasses each of the elements of basic research, applied research and experimental development, which are explained in greater detail in the Explanatory Memorandum that will be made available to Honourable Senators.

The definition also includes other activities undertaken in direct support of activities falling within the central definition. These include (but are not limited to) industrial design, engineering design, production engineering, operations research, mathematical modelling and analysis, psychological research and computer software development.
Computer software development which meets the central criteria and which is for sale, rent, licence, hire or lease to multiple clients is included in the definition of eligible activities.

The design, construction and operation of prototypes where the objective is technical testing or improvements, the construction of pilot plants used as experimental models and ``feedback R&D'', aimed at problem solving beyond the R&D phase, are also eligible activities.

The Bill excludes a number of activities that are not systematic, investigative or experimental activities involving innovation or technical risk. These include market research, market testing, quality control, cosmetic modifications or stylistic changes and management studies. Other activities not specifically identified in the Bill but which fall outside the definition are:
Pre-production activities such as demonstration of commercial viability, tooling-up, trial and production runs;
routine data collection;
preparing for teaching;
costs of patenting or copywriting the results of R&D work;
specialised routine medical care;
duplication of commercial products or processes.
The Bill provides that the Industry Research and Development Board may determine whether particular activities are research and development within the meaning of this definition:
Where the Commissioner of Taxation has doubts as to whether, in fact, certain activities are R&D, the Commissioner can refer the matter to the Board for determination.

Except for expenditure on R&D activities contracted out to approved research institutions (as defined in sub-section 73a (6) of the Income Tax Assessment Act), the 150 per cent rate of deduction will be available where total annual expenditure in the year of income is $50,000 or more. Where annual expenditure is less than $50,000 but more than $20,000, a deduction will be available at a phased-in rate of between 100 per cent and 150 per cent, determined on a formula basis provided in the Bill. Expenditure on R&D carried out by an approved research institute on behalf of an eligible company will attract the 150 per cent deduction irrespective of the level of that expenditure.

The Bill provides that expenditure on contracted-out R&D, salary and salary-related expenditure and other expenditure of a current nature, is allowable as a deduction at 150 per cent of costs in the year incurred. Expenditure on plant and equipment used exclusively for R & D (including up to $10 million of expenditure on a unit of pilot plant) is to be deductible at 150 per cent over three years in three equal amounts. Expenditure on buildings or building extensions, alterations or improvements used exclusively for R&D activities is deductible at 100 per cent of costs over three years in three equal amounts.

The Government is concerned that maximum benefits should accrue to Australia from commercialisation of the R&D work subsidised by the proposed concession. No concession will be allowed where the Industry Research and Development Board certifies that any commercialisation of the results of R&D activities is otherwise than on normal commercial terms or otherwise than in a manner for the benefit of the Australian economy.

The Bill also contains safeguards provisions to prevent abuse of the taxation concession. For example, if a building attracts the concession on the basis that it is to be used exclusively for R&D activities-so that its cost is written off over three years-and it is subsequently used for other purposes within five years, the deductions allowed will, in ordinary circumstances, be withdrawn.

The Bill provides for this taxation concession to operate in respect of expenditure incurred during the period 1 July 1985 to 30 June 1991. It is the Government's intention that there will be a rigorous cost/effectiveness study on broadly-based criteria before decisions are made about its continuation beyond 30 June 1991.
In addition to the cost effectiveness review, there will be a technical review of the concession by mid-1987, to allow consideration of any desirable administrative changes.

In conclusion, there are encouraging signs that this proposed measure is being enthusiastically accepted by Australian industry. There is widespread support for the concession from the industrial and scientific community. Together with the grants scheme for research and development, I am confident this proposed concession will lead to a significant increase in R&D activity in the private sector and an enhanced capacity for Australian industry to participate in the global development and exploitation of new technology.
Financial Impact Statement

The cost of the concession depends primarily on the level of R&D investment by companies. For 1986-87 the cost is estimated at approximately $100m. This is based on data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the rate of increase in R&D advised by companies registering their intention to make claims under this concession in respect of the 1985-86 year of income. Costs in later years are less certain but may be of the order of $140 million in 1987-88, with annual costs, when the scheme is taken up in full, of $160 million.

These little anomalies are coming forward all the time. I would like the Minister to take into consideration the fact that business is absolutely terrified of this fringe benefits tax. Senator Walsh told us in his second reading speech that he believes he is going to collect $330m in the first year of operation of this tax. I would like Senator Walsh to comment on some figures I have and to tell me whether they are right or wrong. In the car industry alone the Federal Government is going to miss out on $82m in sales tax and $15m in import duty. There will be a $49m loss in company tax and a loss of $70m in income tax in respect of retrenched workers. Of course, we are not considering the dole payments that will have to be made to the 10,000 retrenched workers. The Commonwealth will lose a total of $276m in revenue.

In addition, the State revenues that will be lost as a result of this tax include $8m in payroll tax, $11m in stamp duty and $3m in registration fees. The total loss in respect of the car industry will be $298m. I wonder whether Senator Walsh can tell me whether that is an accurate figure because--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is bullshit.
—Order! Senator Walsh, that kind of language is not acceptable in this chamber. I ask you to withdraw it immediately.
—Yes, Mr Temporary Chairman. I could not think of any other word which so aptly describes the quality of what is being dished up.
—Senator Walsh, I ask you to withdraw that remark unconditionally.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I am offended by that remark. I think it is absolutely disgraceful that a senior Minister should use that sort of language in this chamber.

—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. I did not prepare these figures; they were prepared by the Federated Chamber of Automotive Industries. The figures were not prepared by Ron Boswell or any other senator in this chamber. They were put down by an industry group representing the motor vehicle industry. Other senators have probably had representations from car distributors in their own States. One distributor told me that he is sustaining a sales fall of 28 to 30 per cent. I have been told that most businesses can sustain a 10 or 15 per cent sales drop. However, there is very little future for an industry which is sustaining a 30 per cent sales drop.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the mining industry also needs to be discussed. I understand that it will cost the mining industry $61m to provide fringe benefits that are absolutely necessary. —We know the people you represent do not do anything themselves.

—I am finding these remarks continually offensive. Does Senator Walsh expect the rural industry to provide accommodation? Where does he expect people working on farms 30, 40 or 50 miles from the nearest town to live? Also, has Senator Walsh considered that many farmers give their retired workers a cottage for use in their retirement in return for turning on a pump, feeding the chooks or being general caretakers? These people have given their working life to particular property owners. In return, the property owners have turned over a cottage and said: `Look, you can live there rent free-just look after the place when we are not here'. Where are those workers, whom the Australian Labor Party is supposed to represent, going to live? They will have to live in old people's homes because there is nowhere else for them to go. I would like Senator Walsh to put forward some propositions on where rural workers are supposed to live. Also, I would like him to tell us something about mining companies and shipping companies.

SPEECH.PARA: For goodness sake, I want him to tell us whether a book can be written in simple terms that people can understand. It was conceived by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and given birth by Senator Haines. It is interesting, of course, that in giving birth to it, Senator Haines has obviously been pressured by the car industry. It is interesting to see that the Australian Democrats can be crushed by pressure. However, perhaps they have not been crushed hard enough. The car industry is very vulnerable to this legislation. I am afraid that the debate which has taken place on the car industry has sadly tended to obscure the fact that this Bill will apply to business generally and that all industry will be the poorer. Of course, employment and inflation will also suffer. The spare parts industry, which is very dependent on the car industry, is another area which has not received much attention.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the fact that some deal has been done by the wheeling and dealing Democrats who, as a result, have lost credibility throughout the country, does not hide the fact that there is still a big slug on the motor vehicle industry and that other people will suffer very badly as a result of the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have saved the car industry $200m a year.

I was interested to hear the claim of Senator Haines on Friday that she is hardly likely to lose a large percentage of her votes because she is supporting something which is equitable and moral. SPEECH.PARA: The administrative nightmare that small businesses will face and the enormous costs imposed by this legislation are appalling to consider. It is really only now that small businessmen are grabbing the time to go to seminars to find out what their responsibilities will be under this legislation, and they are appalled and very frightened. Even the Commissioner of Taxation has not been able to get it right. The lilac or purple book-it is a multicoloured book, by the sound of things-is certainly a horror book full of mistakes which have had to be rectified. I am sure that we have not seen the last of those mistakes yet. If the Commissioner of Taxation cannot get it right, how can the small businessman who is struggling to do his books at midnight? He has to take the place of a workman in his business because he cannot afford all the employees he would like to have, so he has to get his hands dirty and do his books at night. We know that is a fact of life throughout this country. The farmers, whom Senator Walsh likes to ridicule, the ones with dirty and broken fingernails, are also trying to do their books at night, so it would pay him to treat them with a little more respect. They are the producers of this country, which is more than can be said for him.

The proprietor of a small firm who does his books by lamplight, if he does not do the books himself, usually will employ someone who is not highly paid and does not have high qualifications. That employee will now have to go because the small businessman will have to have his books done by an accountant. As a number of speakers in this debate have said, this legislation will be a bonanza for the accountants-about the only profession that will do well out of this legislation.

These costs will have to be passed on-the costs both of the taxes themselves and of the administration of the legislation. Where will they be passed on? They will be passed on to the consumers, or employees will have to lose their jobs. The manager of one factory in my State has said the he has done his sums and has worked out how much the business will be liable to pay, which equates to the cost of employing four or five employees. That is fine and fair and everybody thinks we should have an equitable tax system in this country. I certainly agree with that, so long as it is clearly understood that Senator Walsh wants to see that the employees of Australia will pay more tax. I thought the Government was claiming that it would cut tax, but this is obviously a misapprehension on my part. The Government is looking for more, but has not thought about cutting back its expenditure. From talking to people in my constituency, it is interesting to find a slight difference in attitude between big and small firms. It is worth making a comment in passing that big business tends to be not nearly so worried or concerned about this tax, for a very interesting reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have had a look at the figures, that is why.

—Not at all. It is because one talks to the middle management of big business, who will continue to get their perks, paid for in the first place by the company and in the second place by the consumer. They are not bothered at all; but we will all pay, firstly, as consumers and, secondly, in the long run as a nation through inflation. If we do not have unemployment we will have additional costs. Which way does Senator Siddons want it? This is a Keating-Haines Bill, conceived by the Treasurer and given birth to by Senator Haines and her fellow Democrats, and the buck stops with them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address myself to a few issues. Firstly, the fringe benefits tax has been described by others as immoral because the power already exists to collect taxes on employees' benefits. The fact that there has been an administration problem and the Australian Taxation Office has been unable to administer the Income Tax Assessment Act as it is already is no excuse for an additional 179 pages of legislation and an explanatory memorandum of even greater length. The administration will be an absolute nightmare, not just for the employers but also for the Taxation Office. To fortify that statement, I remind the chamber that I have had a number of calls from people in the Australian Taxation Office who have attended seminars and their advice to us was to try to prevent the legislation going through because they felt they could not administer it.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to address the cashing out of fringe benefits. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has said on a number of occasions that if people do not like this they can cash out the fringe benefit. That might be all right for contrived salary packages. It seems to me that the Government and the Minister for Finance have a fixation with people who have contrived salary packages, but they are by far the minority of those who will be affected by this quite outlandish legislation.

It is estimated that in the tourist industry this fringe benefits tax will mean a net increase over 12 months of something like 20 per cent in the cost of providing tourist services. I remind the Government and the Minister that the tourist industry has been one of the great growth areas, particularly in my State of Queensland, despite other adverse factors such as penalty rates, which are a ridiculous anachronism today. A lot of tourist areas are on island resorts. How on earth can fringe benefits be cashed out on an island resort? There is nowhere else to stay. I mention that as an example, but it applies also to motels and hotels. In a 24-hour industry it is expected that the manager of a hotel or motel will live on the premises. It is anticipated that the tax will cost an ordinary size motel in a tourist area in the order of $25,000 per year, before administering it.

The ability to cash out fringe benefits in the mining industry will be an absolute impossibility. In mining towns the infrastructure-houses, water, power, railway lines, roads and communications-are paid for entirely by the mining company without any cost whatsoever to the taxpayer. The mining companies will now be penalised for providing that infrastructure, which was done at their own expense. If there were a market for houses in mining towns, I am sure that the houses would be sold. The Government will be aware that the only way employees can be attracted to mining towns is for the companies to provide certain infrastructures, such as housing, at reduced rates. By way of example, when the Hunter Valley and Port Kembla areas had difficulties some years ago and many miners were put off, the miners were recruited in central Queensland and were given the same fringe benefits which applied to all the miners who worked in Blackwater, Moranbah and Dysart. The interesting thing was that when the market recovered the workers all went back to New South Wales, despite the so-called high fringe benefits. So the cashing out is an impossibility. Even if the companies wished to cash out, they would have to offer the houses for sale to their employees at very low rates. If they did that, they would be classed as fringe benefits and they would have to pay tax on what was considered to be the market price, as against the price that would be received if the houses were sold on the open market. So there is a contrived and statutory formula that applies-I think the figure is about $35 per man per week-to every home in every mining town in Australia. The cost to a small company at South Blackwater is approximately $1m, which completely wipes out the profit. When that company decided to shut its underground mine and put about 400 people off the payroll, direct responsibility will have to be borne by this Government. I turn briefly to educational and charitable institutions. At Question Time in the Senate--

TALK.START.PARA: —We will come to that later in the Bill. Is this under the general administration aspect or are you referring to particular matters?
—It is general administration, Mr Chairman.
—You should not ask questions about particular matters. That will come later in the debate.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I will refer briefly to educational and charitable institutions. It has been claimed that the Catholic Family Welfare Bureau in South Australia approved of what the Government had done. This must have been the only letter that the Government received in support of the fringe benefits tax. It also shows that the person who wrote that letter or who made that comment had not received his little mauve booklet or that he had not read it, because the general consensus of views of all educationalists and of people engaged in charitable work is that it will cost them enormous amounts of money. I have concentrated on the cashing out aspect of fringe benefits. For instance, when the Catholic Education Office in Brisbane was asked whether it should cash out, its reply was that if it decided not to have vehicles, the cost to it of employees providing their own vehicles would break the charity. So charitable institutions, the mining industry and people in the tourist industry cannot cash out in regard to these so-called fringe benefits. Obviously, as a corollary of this, if this fringe benefits tax is passed-it is apparent that it will go through with the support of the Australian Democrats, except for one minor amendment-it will mean that less money will be available for welfare, education and other services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage I will make only a few brief remarks in dealing with the general question of administration of this legislation. I draw attention to one particularly disturbing element of the legislation which means that it will apply in situations where a business has made, or is making, a loss. Even though it is making a loss and it would not otherwise be liable to pay any other taxation, it will now be liable to pay the fringe benefits tax. It seems to me that this will impose an extraordinary burden, particularly on the rural sector. Very few people in the rural sector will be able to report any profits or will have available any funds out of their trading to do much more than survive, let alone pay a tax when they have made no profit. It seems to me to be less than intelligent for the Government at this time to provide yet another disincentive of this nature. This point has been made by honourable senators during many second reading debates. It emerges, of course, because the tax is to be imposed on the employer, not the employee. We have heard of the impact of that on charitable and other organisations. That will no doubt be raised again, of course, at the appropriate time during this Committee stage debate. But it is worth stressing that not only will it have an unfair impact on non-profitmaking organisations, but also in effect it will place an added burden on those enterprises which are suffering losses.
—We are moving an amendment on this aspect.
—Yes. I am glad to hear that the Australian Democrats are sufficiently concerned to be doing something positive in this case.
—Not too much.

—Not too much. I think that is a reasonable interjection. Certainly they have done enough in terms of deals with the Government to ensure that this offensive and oppressive legislation is passed. I will read to the Committee one of the many letters I have received on this matter because I think it sums up the concerns-the very proper concerns-that small business people have. The letter is from a Mr R. S. Dawson of Roydens Menswear in Cronulla. His letter reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Last Tuesday I received from the Department of Taxation a 56-page booklet outlining the proposed Fringe Benefits Tax. Since then, I understand that this legislation has passed through the House of Representatives.

I feel that the Government has deliberately misled the Australian public over the number of people this legislation will affect. It will, in a time of high interest rates and low consumer spending, add a further burden upon every individual Australian and business. I must also point out that it is a direct attack upon the business community. Taxing businesses giving employees a benefit, not the person who is receiving the benefit, would appear to be in contradiction of the Australian income tax system.

This tax is a direct charge on all business, and will cause a subsequent loss in profit, with all its ramifications, i.e., loss of jobs, inflation, and further wage demands, thus worsening the Australian economic position.
I would urge that the legislation be most vigorously opposed in the Parliament.

I must say that there is no need for him to urge the Opposition to do that. I suggest that he might direct his enthusiasm towards the Democrats who have, of course, done this deal with the Government so that this legislation will be passed. He continues:

The effects of this regressive legislation on the economy, the cost of administration, in both Government and private business, and the effect on the general public should be fully aired in the public forum. The above points cannot be expressed strongly enough, thus making the Government fully aware of the Australian people's anger and disgust at yet another unjustifiable tax, in order to finance the Government's gross incompetence in its handling of the Australian economy.
Mr Dawson is simply reflecting the general view, I believe, of the great bulk of small businesses around Australia. For that reason I have referred to his letter at this stage in the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to Part II, Administration, clause 4, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commissioner shall, as soon as practicable after 30 June in each year, prepare and furnish to the Minister a report on the working of this Act-
that refers to the annual report-
including any breaches or evasions of this Act of which the Commissioner has notice.

I wanted to ask a question of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who is handling the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill in the Senate. I find it very difficult to ask him any questions because he is not present. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, who is present, is not sitting near his advisers. I feel that the Government is handling this matter in a very superficial way if the Minister is not prepared to be present to defend his Bill. I want to find out from the Minister why this clause is contained in the Bill. Is there such a clause in any other comparable Bill? Is it a method of attempting to intimidate the taxpayers by saying that their names and any breaches will be included in the annual report and will be tabled by the Minister in this place? I am at a loss to understand why it is contained in the Bill. I have quite a bit more to say on this matter. I will await the arrival of the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it amazing that about six or seven speakers from the Liberal and National parties have dealt with very important questions of administration, but the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has not been present to answer them. The Minister has just arrived. Perhaps he can answer those questions for us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just had virtually another second reading debate. The Liberal Party of Australia has picked yet another political lemon and now it has to suck it. On this matter, as with its passionate defence of the free lunch, it is offside with the people. It is absurd, to say the least, that those who argue-as most Opposition senators do-that there is nothing wrong in principle with the taxing of fringe benefits or, more accurately, of income paid in kind rather than cash, criticise this legislation on the basis of the resources that it will consume in administration. It is absurd that the same people should then complain that the administration of this legislation in the form in which it has been introduced by the Government will require more bureaucrats.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner asked how many extra bureaucrats there would be. If this measure is taken in isolation there certainly will be a requirement for significant additional resources in the Australian Taxation Office. However, some of the other policy changes in areas which required greater numbers of people for the initial administration do not need so many and these numbers will be phased out, giving a gross figure and a net figure. That number has not yet been determined and, indeed, there are very few departments which, at this stage, have determined their staffing levels for the next financial year. It is nothing at all unusual that the ATO staff levels have not yet been determined by the Government because that is the position for most departments. We have not started determining the levels for the next financial year.

Senator Messner also asked what would happen as a result of the pressure on the availability of accountancy services where there are quarterly returns-in particular, on 1 October. Extensions will be fairly readily granted as they are fairly readily granted by the Australian Taxation Office to the 31 August requirement for self-employed people lodging their returns. I would have thought that Senator Messner would know that. That was rather spurious criticism. Anyway, the Government's preferred response to this tax is that the benefits be cashed out, thereby avoiding all the administrative problems, both for employers and the Australian Taxation Office. The option is available for employers to cash out benefits and if they are really worried about what they claim is an onerous responsibility for their part of the administration, they can exercise the option. The Government hopes that most employers will take that option. From the public perspective there will be the additional benefit of the requirement for public resources being reduced as well.

Senator Reid raised some questions about the administration of the provisional payments system. This is not the subject of this Bill, but I am glad she mentioned it because she reminded me of an incident that happened in Perth nearly three years ago. The PPS, which had been foreshadowed by the Fraser Government in about September 1982, was brought into operation on 1 September 1983 by this Government. I attended a meeting in Perth of the Confederation of Western Australian Industry, a group of people who were complaining about the PPS which was about to be introduced. They made the same sorts of dire predictions about the effect that the PPS would have on economic activity as various members of the Opposition have been about the fringe benefits tax today and on other occasions. I fronted up to these people and I told them that I regretted that the facts were still being misrepresented in an advertisement which appeared in the Western Australian newspaper that morning and which had been inserted by the Confederation of Western Australian Industry. The advertisement asserted that the PPS was a turnover tax. I told the officials that it was not a turnover tax and if they did not know that they were guilty of culpable negligence and ignorance, and if they did know it they were guilty of wilful misrepresentation. We have seen yet again the situation whereby whenever a government takes action to close off some lurk or perk in the taxation law there is an orgy of culpable ignorance and wilful misrepresentation.

Senator Walters asked about the cost of this measure to the rural sector. That has not been quantified because it will be so insignificant. If honourable senators want a rule of thumb, I suggest that they take whatever figure is given by the National Farmers Federation and divide it by some number between 10 and 100. Senator Walters and others also asked about the cost of the mauve booklet. I cannot give that specifically but last week I answered a general question about expenditure in both this and next financial year for the supply and or distribution of information on the taxation system and I believe that it is of the order of $3m. I apologise for not having that figure accurately checked out, but it is something of that order.

We heard from Senator Newman-and in varying degrees the same proposition was put by a number of other Opposition senators-that the cost of this tax would be borne by business and that it would bankrupt it. We also heard that the cost would be passed on to consumers in higher prices and that it would crank up inflation. Then we heard that it would be passed back to employees. In other words, we heard three mutually exclusive propositions put forward about the effects of this tax. Opposition senators cannot have it two ways, let alone three. There are a number of amendments forecast, some of which the Government will accept, and I suggest that the Committee proceed to deal with those specific amendments and the other clauses of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Either deliberately or because he was not aware of it, the Minister for Finance has not answered my question about clause 4. I asked why the Commissioner of Taxation, in furnishing his annual report, would give the Minister a report including any breaches or evasions of this legislation which the Commissioner had noticed. I asked whether this was a method of intimidation. Is the Government saying to the people: `If you assess yourselves incorrectly, we can assure you that your breaches will be tabled in the Parliament and your names will reach every corner of Australia? I cannot see any other reason for the inclusion of that information in the annual report. I hope the Minister will answer that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister also failed to answer a question I asked in talking about the costing of the lilac book. Seeing that the Government and the Australian Democrats have come to a deal and the Government was foolish enough to send out the lilac book before the legislation passed the Senate, will the Minister now have to send out another booklet containing the correct information? What does the Government intend to do? Senator Walsh said he did not know how much the lilac book cost and that is a disgrace. He should know the wastage involved in sending out that book when the legislation had not even passed the Senate. The Minister said he had no idea about the cost of this tax to the rural community-the words he used were that it had not been quantified. I rang the office of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and I asked Mr Greg Smith about the cost to rural industry. He said that that cost was not available for me to know. I said: `Surely that does not mean you have not done your sums and you do not know what the cost will be to the community?'. He replied: `I did not say that, Senator; I said that we are not divulging the cost to you or anyone else'. Obviously either the Treasurer knows and has not told the Minister or the Minister is right and the Treasury has not bothered to find out what the cost will be to the rural community.

As the Minister may well know, I have done some sums on this, getting the figures from the Bureau of Agricultural Economics and from the Parliamentary Library. I want to know whether my figures are anywhere near correct. If they are correct, the Minister will find that in Tasmania alone the accommodation of one farmhand, using the Treasurer's figures, is worth $40 a week. He is supplied with 12 kilos of meat at $2 a kilo and is allowed to have milk from the property. Electricity, at very conservative prices, will cost the employer $1,592 a year. I am presuming that every cottage on the farm is considered to be in an isolated area and am allowing for the $200 threshold.

I want to find out from the Minister whether my figure is accurate. I know other figures are available. The Livestock and Grain Producers Association has assessed the total cost to the rural community at $150m. I have just calculated the cost of a single farm hand employed on a typical farm in Tasmania. I ask the Minister whether my figures are anywhere near correct. We have to remember that the Livestock and Grain Producers Association has calculated a figure of $150m at a time when the rural community, according to the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, is at an all time low. The bureau estimates that rural income has dropped by two thirds. It says that the average net farm income has dropped from $19,470 in 1984-85 to an estimate of $6,700 this year at a time when the rural community is in recession and when this Government is wanting the rural industry to help it out of its balance of payments problems. The Government believes that because the rural and mining industries are such large exporters of goods they need to help Australia out of its balance of payments problems.

The Government is wacking this tax on the employer and not on the employee. The Minister keeps telling us that he would like the employer to cash it out, to make his employees pay this tax. But the Government has taken the easy way out because it knows the industrial problems that would arise if it put the tax where it should go-on the person receiving the benefit. The Government is not game to do it, so it has taken the easy option. It knows that the unions will not pay, so it has said: `We will make the employer pay'. It has taken the easy way out. The Minister has the hide to say in this place that the Government hopes that the employer will do the job for it and levy the tax where it should be levied-on the person receiving the benefit. It is a ridiculous situation. I again ask the Minister whether he will answer the questions which I have put to him and which he has not yet answered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not in the chamber when Senator Walters referred to clause 4, so I did not hear her remarks about it. Incidentally, for Senator Walters's information, although it was a general practice under the Income Tax Assessment Act for defaulters above a certain level to be named in the Parliament, that is no longer the case and it will not be the case with breaches of this legislation either. Individuals will not be named in the annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the honourable senator's hotchpotch of figures about farms in Tasmania, for a start, farmers do not get $2 a kilo for meat. If they were getting $2 a kilo they would be very much better off than they are. On the question of farm incomes, the honourable senator used the Bureau of Agricultural Economics figure for net farm income, which is not the same as taxable income. That is particularly important in respect of the changes in net farm income as defined by the BAE between last year and this year, because the average depreciation allowance, which is not cash outgoing at all but a tax write off for wheat farmers, is of the order of $27,000. So that figure is quite unreliable.

A few people have said something about farms and a period of rural recession. I leave aside the land barons who have large numbers of employees, and are usually companies or millionaires of one form or another, of whom, I suppose, the President of the National Farmers Federation would be a prime example. That perhaps accounts for why he is making such a fuss about this. In this instance, as in so many others, he is speaking for himself rather than the people he purports to represent. Firstly, the majority of farms in Australia do not employ full time labour at all. Most of those which do, have one employee, and in a period of real stress that employee tends to get the sack. I have never noticed members of the National Party in particular or the Liberal Party weeping too many tears in the past for rural employees who got the sack either because of a drought or because of a severe economic recession in agriculture.
