This is arguably the most important part of the fringe benefits tax legislation. A major portion of the revenue the Government intends to raise will come from the fringe benefits tax on company cars. Of the total $540m foreshadowed by the Government, $370m was estimated to be gathered from the taxing of company cars. When the Australian Democrats discussed the whole tax package with the Government late last year, we agreed to pass the fringe benefits tax legislation including the taxing of company cars principally on the basis of very substantial concessions the Government made to the Democrats, particularly the promise that it would deliver the tax cuts. We have stuck to our bargain. We have stuck to the arrangement to which we came with the Government.

We support the fringe benefits taxation but we do so with some very important amendments. The Government claimed that it was going to raise $370m from the taxing of company cars. It became very obvious to us-as a result of approaches by the motor car industry itself, by the dealers and distributors, and by the car unions-that this tax would raise much more money than the Government had estimated, and that between 10,000 to 20,000 jobs were at stake. We looked into the government figures very carefully, and we found wide discrepancies. For instance, the industry, as a result of surveys, said that something like 550,000 motor cars would be subject to this Tax. The Government had estimated that the revenue would come from something like 470,000 motor cars. The industry, the unions, and the distributors had done their homework. As a result of the surveys which we studied carefully there was very little doubt in our mind that at least 550,000 motor cars would be involved. We said that even if we take an average of the two figures we would still have a figure of something like 500,000 motor cars.

We looked into other aspects of the Government's assessments. For instance, there was a difference of something like $100m between what the industry and what the Government said in relation to how many cars would be garaged over the weekends; and so it went on. After much argument, after much negotiation and after the weight of the evidence that was on our side, the Government has finally, as I understand it, agreed to support the amendment that I have just moved on behalf of the Democrats.

Initially, in a full year the Government planned to levy a tax on 24 per cent, 16 per cent and 8 per cent of the value of a motor car, depending on the distance that that car travelled in each year. Our amendment is as follows: On a car that travels less than 15,000 kilometres per year, the tax will be levied on 24 per cent of the total value of the motor car; on a car travelling between 25,000 and 40,000 kilometres per year, the tax will be levied on 10 per cent of the value of the motor car; and for cars travelling over 40,000 kilometres per year, the tax will be levied on 6 per cent of the value of the motor car. The new tax will result in a significant drop in the burden of tax on company cars.

There is no doubt that the Australian Democrats will have won a very significant victory if the amendment is passed. On the arithmetic of the calculation alone, there is no doubt that employers will be saved at least $200m a year. That calculation is beyond dispute. The facts of the matters are simply these: The Government has come up with figures that are not realistic. If we take the surveyed figures-the realistic figures-there is little doubt that the Government would be raising $570m, not the $370m that it estimates it will be raising. The difference between those two figures is $200m.

I am afraid that the Democrats are getting very tired of hearing from the Opposition that the concessions that we have wrung from the Government are of a minor nature. We are also getting very tired of reading about that in the Press. The fact of the matter is that the reduction in the percentages of tax on motor cars was put before the Government on no less than three occasions by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and on three occasions the Cabinet refused to agree to them. The industry itself made innumerable approaches to the Government to get the fringe benefit tax on motor cars reduced. The Government stood steadfast and said: `No, our figures are right and this is what we are going to do'. It was not until the Democrats took up the cause and pushed the logic of the position that had been taken up by two Labor State governments, by all sections of the manufacturing industry, by the distribution industry, by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the motor car unions that the Government conceded. We pushed the position with which all sections of the car industry were in complete agreement. I repeat that the concession is $200m.

If the concession that the Democrats have wrung from the Government is minor, I would like to know what a major one is. The $200m concession is an indisputable fact. One only has to multiply the figures. It does not sound much when one talks about a three, four or five percentage reduction. However, if one multiplies that reduction over the number of motor cars involved, one can see that the concession which has been conceded by the Government, assuming that the Government agrees to our amendment now before the Committee, will reduce the estimated revenue by $200m. One might wonder how the Government can possibly go ahead with the tax cuts if it is going to lose $200m. The dispute is over the base statistics-that is, how many cars are involved. We say that 500,000 motor cars are involved; the Government says that a considerably lesser number is involved. We are prepared to have another look at this matter if our figures are wrong over a period of 12 months or thereabouts. In the meantime, the arithmetic shows that employers will be saved $200m in respect of the tax on motor cars.

This is in fact a victory of the philosophy of industry development over a doctrinaire economic rationalist approach by the Treasury. The Democrats have been engaged in long hours of negotiation between all sectors of the industry. Our amendment represents the consensus of opinion of all sections of the industry. The four major motor car manufacturers-namely, General Motors-Holdens Ltd, Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd, Mitsubishi Motors Australia Ltd and Toyota-all agree that the amendments will save between 10,000 and 20,000 jobs. How can the Opposition possibly say that the saving of 10,000 to 20,000 jobs is a minor concession by the Government? It is a major victory for negotiation; it is a major victory for commonsense. It is something that required enormous effort on the part of the Democrats. Perhaps honourable senators can understand why we feel a little touchy on this matter when we are repeatedly accused of winning minor concessions. I commend this amendment to the Committee. I hope that commonsense will prevail and that the amendment will be agreed to by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be opposing the amendment that is proposed by the Australian Democrats. However, I wish that the Democrats would save us the humbug of their posturing in this place about how they have saved the car industry. They have given the car industry a choice: Instead of shooting itself with a .387 magnum, it can do it with a .303 rifle. That is the kind of difference they have made to this legislation which, without a doubt, will still have a devastating impact on the motor vehicle industry. I speak particularly of the impact upon my own State of South Australia and, of course, the motor vehicle industry which is centred there.

SPEECH.PARA: Whatever the outcome of the particular measures that are put forward in this legislation, it is quite clear that the Government of South Australia and the Vehicle Builders Union of South Australia are still conducting a massive campaign of resistance against this tax because they know quite simply that there are jobs on the line in the car industry as a result of this new tax. Try as they may, whether the Democrats think that they have saved the nation, saved jobs in South Australia or the motor vehicle industry, they will fail because the jobs are going to go west as a result of this measure. Whether or not Senator Siddons is prepared to admit this, it certainly is true. The Government of South Australia says that, Mr Bannon the Labor Premier of South Australia says that and so does the Vehicle Builders Union in that State. That is quite independent of what the Opposition is saying. Our estimates, of course, are similar.

However, the fact is that we do not rely on our own information; we rely on information from alternative, so-called independent sources which apparently the Democrats are not prepared to heed. I think it is amazing that in a State like South Australia, which has such a narrow industrial base and which relies so heavily upon the motor vehicle industry and the associated componentry industry, the two Democrat senators elected by the people of South Australia are not prepared to stand up in the Senate and oppose this legislation with the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not even in the chamber.

—I did not notice them during the earlier debate on this matter and consequently one is drawn to the conclusion that they are ashamed to stand in this place and defend their own position. The fact is that the Democrats, including Senator Haines and Senator Vigor, have let down South Australia and they will pay the price at the ballot box as a result.

SPEECH.PARA: Another issue is of major concern. Quite apart from the jobs issue, which clearly is going to have a dramatic impact upon the industrial development of South Australia, there are associated indirect effects. Senator Michael Baume, when speaking in the second reading debate on this Bill, drew attention to the effect on the steel industry as a result of fewer cars being sold. The estimates are as high as 90,000 fewer cars being sold as a result of this new tax. Less steel will be sold in the community; consequently, the industries based in Wollongong and Port Kembla will suffer. Senator Baume told us the other day that sheet metal production would be reduced by 20 per cent as a result of the car industry losing sales caused by this tax. That is a huge reduction in the production of sheet steel, which will have a dramatic impact on Australia, especially on those parts already depressed and still trying to come out of the recessions of earlier years. That is something which this Government appears to ignore and about which it is not concerned.

I make one other point in respect of the Democrats. They have postured that they have produced results and have somehow scaled down the impact of this tax. The only reason Senator Siddons has been able to achieve anything at all, small as it is, in seeking to get the Government to change its mind, is that the Liberal and National parties have stood firm in opposition to this tax all the way down the line. That is the only reason the Democrats have been able to play the middle ground and to seek some kind of compromise which in the end will have no positive effect whatsoever. If they try to make heroes of themselves, they will fail absolutely. They should join in opposing this legislation to get rid of the tax altogether. The Democrats know that it is horrendous and wrong.

One of the major arguments that the Democrats have put forward in terms of their own position is that somehow this legislation will save everybody in the community a lot of tax. They have said that the Government's commitment to giving tax cuts this year and next year, which will total some $4,500m, will be financed by this puny fringe benefits tax. Nothing could be further from the truth. In fact, only $1 in $6 which will be saved as a result of the tax cuts, if they come into force, will come from the fringe benefits tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you trust the word of the Prime Minister?

—Trust the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), he says! The Prime Minister went to central and western New South Wales this weekend and did not even know, apparently, until that time that the farmers will be charged the fringe benefits tax upon their residential accommodation. That is how much we trust the Prime Minister in these matters. He does not even understand the issues involved. He goes around parading as somebody in favour of taxation reform, yet fails to understand the impact of the very solutions he is putting forward, which of course are utter failures.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not have any more humbug from the Democrats about how the tax cuts are being preserved as a result of their measures. The people of Australia cannot and should not be misled by this cheap statement that those cuts are being preserved. They are not, because the effect of the fringe benefits tax will be more devastating in its job destruction potential than in delivering extra revenue to provide tax cuts.

During the first stage of the debate on this matter we made it quite clear that the Government's intention to force employers to cash up benefits will lead to the lowest paid employees paying the tax, while the highest paid employees will be able to avoid the tax. The Democrats' nonsense about somehow bringing this new equitable scheme into place is totally wrong. If the Democrats have convinced themselves about that, hopefully they will come to some conversion on this at a later stage. I suggest that that later stage will occur at the next election when they lose seats in South Australia and Victoria as a result of putting up candidates who have defended such an outrageous proposition as this fringe benefits tax.

Quite apart from the argument that has been put about the value of the taxes to be collected-various estimates have been given of $370m or $500m; the numbers are mind-boggling in terms of the number of noughts they have-let us try to understand that the tax is being imposed by the Government at a time when the economy is quite obviously going down the tube. We are now in official recession and we face jobs losses in industries anyway, yet the Government persists with a measure which has the great potential of destroying even more jobs. Various estimates have been made of the amount of tax that will be collected as a result of this legislation, and a figure has been mentioned by Senator Siddons. I received just a few minutes ago an estimate of the cost of the Democrats' proposals for the changes in the car benefits tax. That proposal is supposed to be saving the car industry, but estimates show that the Government, after the implementation of these proposals, will reap a harvest of $620m in tax-far more than was estimated by the Democrats.

I understand that the Democrats have entered into a deal with the Government whereby, if the revenue falls below the Government's minimum level, they will allow the passage of further legislation to impose further taxes on the country to make up the difference. That is the deal these wonderful Democrats have done for the Australian people! They have provided a means for the Government to ensure that it can impose a further tax on the people. That is the Democrats' solution. Following the logic of Senator Siddon's argument, if the figure turns out to be higher than the estimates which have been produced, along the lines I have just mentioned, and is in fact $620m, will Senator Siddons agree to provide a tax cut for the excess?

TALK.START.PARA: —That figure you pulled out of the air has no foundation in any survey at all. The fact is that these amendments will save $200m.

—These figures have been produced by an important body, the Victorian Automobile Chamber of Commerce. That body has important information about the car industry, as Senator Siddons no doubt would know, as it comes from his State of Victoria. This information demonstrates that all Senator Siddons is saying is nonsense and that in the end the measures Senator Siddons is seeking to put in place will be of very little value to the people of Australia.
—Which firm did it?
—The Victorian Automobile Chamber of Commerce.
—It did it itself?

—Yes. I conclude where I started, on the question of the car industry. It is clear that jobs are at stake in that industry. It has been estimated by the South Australian Government, the Premier of South Australia, Mr John Bannon, and the South Australian branch of the Vehicle Builders Union that some 4,500 jobs will be lost in South Australia. Although the figure may not be that high if the revenue does not reach the figure predicted, the fact is that a significant number of jobs will be lost in my State. I oppose the tax on that ground alone. The Liberal and National parties oppose this legislation as well. I make the point absolutely clearly that the Liberal and National parties, upon re-election to government, which I hope will be as soon as possible, will repeal this legislation and will provide more opportunities in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I follow my colleague Senator Messner in speaking about the effect that this measure will have on unemployment in South Australia. The fringe benefits tax will have a devastating effect on South Australia. With great reluctance, I make the observation that, even though many honourable senators describe the Senate as the States House, only the Liberal senators of the South Australian senators are opposing this measure which will have a discriminating effect upon South Australia. The Vehicle Builders Union in my State is loudly and clearly opposed to this measure. The State Opposition, led by John Olsen, is vehemently opposed to this measure. The Premier of South Australia and his colleagues in the State Labor Cabinet, are vehemently opposed to this measure. I lament the fact that, instead of all South Australian senators taking up that united cry of the most informed and responsible groups within our State, only the South Australian Liberal Senators are representing that view in this debate. The Labor senators from South Australia have yielded to the view of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the view of Caucus.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Foreman is a former secretary of the Vehicle Builders Union. It does not require a great exercise of imagination for us to know what lobbying he may have done in the background to try to get this tax completely abolished. But we do not hear a word from him in the Senate, which many of us have described as the States House, which protects the States we represent. In this case a clear position of total opposition to this tax has been adopted by Senator Foreman's closest colleagues in my State. But he is silent. I refer especially to the two Australian Democrat senators from South Australia, Senator Haines and Senator Vigor. They are not involved in this debate. They are not present while this odious measure is being debated. They are not here to put a view on behalf of the Democrats, because I believe they are locked into the shoddy compromise that has been worked out in a back room by representatives of the Democrats and the Hawke Labor Government. So even though many of us from time to time will refer to the Senate as a States House, this a clear example of a lack of unanimity amongst honourable senators from South Australia on a matter which has such direct, discriminatory effects on my State.

Various estimates have been made as to the amount of tax that will be raised as a result of this measure. A figure of $500m has been mentioned. Senator Messner has just received from the Automobile Chamber of Commerce an estimate that it could be $650m. But in South Australia the car industry has enormous capital and resource commitments in General Motors-Holden's Ltd, Mitsubishi Australia Ltd and the automotive component industry. For 40 years South Australia has been a major centre for the car industry, in the same way that it is distinctively a centre for the grape, wine and brandy industry. When the Government contrives to introduce measures against an industry as a whole which is predominantly concentrated in one State, I still believe it is appropriate for all honourable senators from that State to make it very clear that the measure will have a disproportionate effect on their State. We have done this in the past with regard to some other measures. I refer to measures affecting South Australians, such as water quality and quantity in the River Murray. But in regard to a measure such as this, I am profoundly disappointed, as a person who believes in the Senate and in the role of honourable senators representing their own States, that only Liberal senators of the South Australian senators are opposing this measure which will put thousands of South Australians out of employment, which will have a tragic effect upon their own and their families' fortunes.

Whilst making this general lament, I believe that the people of South Australia should know and evaluate the actions of the Democrat senators from South Australia who have so lamentably let down South Australians. When the next election comes around, Senator Haines and Senator Vigor will seek to put forward their credentials for re-election. I believe South Australians should remember this day and this debate, when those honourable senators did not oppose this measure which will have such a devastating effect on South Australia. They did not even come into the chamber to listen to the debate and they are not prepared to put forward their own views on the measure. They may have private views on it. If they vote against it, they will swell the Liberal and National Party numbers to ensure its defeat. I believe those honourable senators are neglecting their duty by not putting their view on this measure, which will have a devastating effect on the car industry and on employment in South Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We heard Senator Siddons-by the way, he is not present at the moment; he has moved his amendment and is no longer here-say that the deal done with the Government was considered by the car industry as a whole as saving it an enormous amount of money. Yet the Australian Democrats, I believe, received 25 metres of telexes before their staff turned off the telex machines. They could not bear to receive any more telexes, telling them how much support they lacked in the community. I guess most of that lack of support would have been from the motor industry in South Australia. Senator Siddons also told us that he has a deal in writing with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). He then asked: `Don't we believe the Prime Minister's word? Wouldn't we take the Prime Minister's word?'. Yet he has been forced to seek the Prime Minister's word in writing, instead of seeking a verbal promise, such as the promise that we all heard during the election campaign when the Prime Minister said: `In words that even the Opposition can understand, there will be no capital gains tax'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats wonder why we are not prepared to accept the Prime Minister's word. We will never accept the Prime Minister's word. We do not pass legislation on the basis of the Prime Minister's word. The way in which the Democrats do so has earned the criticism of every editorial across the country. Every editorial across the country has criticised the integrity of the Democrats. It is dishonest to talk only about the car industry while every single small business, farmer and individual will be paying the price of this fringe benefits tax. We have seen an open letter to Senator Chipp, signed by D. G. Mactaggart. He put it pretty clearly when he stated:
This Country can no longer afford the luxury of having Senators, who have been elected by some 5 per cent of electors, controlling the destiny of the rest of the population.

Even the most lowly of the Democrats has responsibility for shadowing seven portfolios. Is it any wonder that they do not look in any depth at the legislation that is now before the Committee? Senator Siddons has said that the measure as it affects the car industry is the only part of this legislation-the most important part-that needs to be debated. He is far from concerned about the way in which this will affect other small businesses. All big businesses can pass on their costs. We will all pay higher air fares because this tax will be passed on. Sir Peter Abeles has told his staff that he will pay fringe benefits tax and therefore they should not worry. But he will not pay them out of his pocket; we will all get the costs on our air tickets. The people of Australia will then know why their air fares have gone up. Indeed, it has already been announced that air fares will go up and part of the reason for that is the fringe benefits tax.

Now that a deal that has been done between the Australian Democrats and the Government, can the Minister give an undertaking that the tax cuts will come through on time? I do not know whether the Minister would bother putting his word in writing, but at least we would have it recorded in Hansard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fairly well known-but perhaps I should put it on the record officially-that the Government will accept the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats. We believe that it is based largely on a misconception, but we will accept it because it is important that the Bill as a whole be retained. I wish to make a few other brief comments. I have noted that both Senator Messner and Senator Teague have identified themselves with delegates from the Vehicle Builders Union. I did not know that that was part of their role as Liberal Party senators, but that is what they say and I accept their word for it. They are controlled by the VBU.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner went into his usual tirade of prophecies of catastrophes which would follow the introduction of this tax and forecasts of 90,000 tonnes less steel being used and so on. I remember the same honourable senator asserting two years ago that a wine tax of 10 per cent would induce a 14 per cent decline in sales. I have not looked at the figures for a couple of months, but the last time I looked, wine sales were increasing at about the same rate as they had increased in previous years. The only logical conclusion one can draw from that is that the 10 per cent sales tax on wine has had no effect on consumption. But logic never has been the strong point of the Liberal Party of Australia or the Opposition in general.

TALK.START.PARA: —He also voted for the brandy excise in 1978 which devastated the South Australian brandy industry.

—He voted for a brandy excise in 1978, did he? So he is highly selective about whether he stands up for South Australian interests or does not. It depends on whether he is an opportunist in opposition or a toady in government.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner has misrepresented the facts. What the Opposition threatened to do and what it says it would have done, had it had the numbers, was torpedo the entire tax reform package and the revenue gained from it. The original estimates were $976m and that amount has been watered down somewhat but the current estimates are that something like $800m in the next financial year will accrue as a result of the tax reform package. The total cost of the tax cuts is of the order of $2 billion, so it is not a one in six ratio, as Senator Messner asserts; it is a ratio of 4:10, which is a great deal different from one in six. In the next year, because of the delayed revenue effect of a number of individual components of the tax package, the revenue gains would be significantly higher.

Senator Walters is so tiresome but I suppose that if I do not answer her now she will only get up and talk again. I will give a guarantee-as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has already done-that the tax cuts forecast in the Treasurer's statement last year will be introduced in 1986.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a couple of points about the statutory formula and the fact that I believe it is discriminatory. I do not believe that the Australian Democrats' objectives will be achieved by this amendment. I give an example of two directors of a company with offices in, say, Martin Place, Sydney. Both have cars worth about $30,000. The first director lives at Darling Point and he drives his car to and from work each day. He is likely to clock up something like 12,000 kilometres each year. The second director lives in Bowral and he drives his car to and from work each day. He is likely to clock up something like 50,000 kilometres each year. Basically both directors travel the same number of kilometres in their cars for private purposes. Under the statutory formula, the first director would be eligible for assessment at 24 per cent, which would be $7,200, and the tax would be 49 per cent of that sum. However, the second director would only be eligible for assessment on $2,400-and under the Democrats' proposal about $1,800-at the rate of 6 per cent. The assumption made by both the Government and the Democrats is that the further one drives one's car, the more likely it is to be for business purposes. I think the above example shows clearly that this is not necessarily so. In my example, the director living close to work is penalised much more than the director who chooses to live elsewhere. Where is the fairness in that?

—The statutory formula is a concession insofar as anyone who chooses not to use it and believes that it treats him more harshly than it should has the option of using a log book and recording the actual number of kilometres travelled. The formula is loaded in favour of the taxpayer because if one is to be taxed on a more than proportional private use under the statutory formula, one has that alternative. If one is taxed less than proportionally under the statutory formula, that is something one gets away with. The only alternative to some sort of statutory formula is to make it mandatory for everyone to keep a log book, which would be demanding of resources in both the private and public sectors. However, from the Opposition's point of view it would have this advantage: The false assertions that the Opposition is making-or at least the Opposition in Western Australia and particularly its State leader, Mr Hassell, who asserts that it is compulsory for everyone to keep a log book-would be true. We chose not to do that, so the Opposition is not telling the truth.

—While we are on the subject of motor vehicles, may I ask the Minister about farm vehicles where there is some short term and fairly limited use for private purposes? I instance the situation in which a farm vehicle is used almost exclusively for running around the paddocks, picking up hay and delivering fencing materials, but on the odd occasion is used to go to town to pick up parts and accessories or supplies from the factory for the farm--
—That is business.

—Let me finish the example. At the same time the farmer takes his wife into town and she goes to have her hair done at the local hairdressing salon and to the local supermarket to buy some groceries for home use. In that situation it seems to me that the car is definitely being used for both business and private purposes. As I read the Bill, this test does not draw distinctions as to the dominant or principal purpose attributable to the use of any vehicle. I may be misreading the legislation because it is so complicated that it is very difficult to get any clear impression. If that assumption is right and there is no test about dominant or principal use, it means if there is any use for private purposes, the car becomes liable for the application of the fringe benefits tax. That is notwithstanding the fact that most of the actual use of the vehicle will be for business or farm purposes. That also means, of course, that proper records would need to be kept on a log book basis in order to keep track of the use of those vehicles for various purposes. I also raise the case of vehicles used to take children off the farm property and on to the road to a bus stop at some point or another each day and then to pick them up afterwards. The farm vehicle would be almost 100 per cent used for farm business except in the circumstances that I have just mentioned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Apparently the rules have changed since I was familiar with them. The use of a farmer's own vehicle-say, a motor car-will be deemed to be one-third business and two-thirds private. If a farmer chooses to substantiate the travel and can establish that more than one-third of it was for business, that substantiated portion is the one that will be used. In the case of driving children to a school bus, that is very clearly not business usage and would not be allowed in a substantiation exercise, if the farmer chose to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not sure whether Senator Messner was asking about farmers or farm employees. If any farm employees are provided with vehicles by the employer-perhaps it happens, although I must say that I have never heard of it-the same rules would prevail. Either the statutory formula will be adopted or, if the taxpayer believes that the statutory formula is unfair to him, he can keep a log book.

TALK.START.PARA: —I may not have made the point absolutely clear. I was talking about a situation where the farmer was in an employee situation, where a company or trust actually owned the farm and conducted the business and employed the farmer as an employee of the farming operation. Having clarified that--
—If they are paid wages, they will be treated as employees.

—In which case the situation that the Minister outlined would apply and the farmer would be caught for the fringe benefits tax. The other point that I would like to make-it is a general one-is that the fringe benefits tax, it seems, is payable in circumstances where a tax deduction has already been denied for the cost of operating vehicles. I instance the situation which applies perhaps to high income earners who are on a fringe benefit salary package and who may have, say, a $90,000 Mercedes Benz provided by the company which, of course, is the main target of the legislation and of the Government in seeking to raise this money. In circumstances where a vehicle of that kind is owned by a company and provided to an employee-executive, the company will receive a deduction for depreciation of that vehicle only up to the maximum limit of $26,660. In other words, the greater part of the vehicle cost will not be allowed as a tax deduction to the company. So the furphy that companies will somehow get a tax deduction for luxury vehicles and things of that kind falls to the ground. On top of that, in circumstance where that deduction is not allowable to companies for income tax purposes, we find that a fringe benefit tax is to be applied on the value of the vehicle as well. In other words, there is to be a double taxation effect on companies in that situation. We were amazed at the Government's failure to recognise that point. It is on about imposing a double tax in a situation where a vehicle is not allowable as a tax deduction anyway.

—We have come to the nitty-gritty of the matter. What the Opposition is about is subsidising, at the expense of general taxpayers, the use of Mercedes Benz and other prestige vehicles by senior executives. That is what the Opposition is on about. It wants to continue a system that subsidises the self-indulgence of senior executives who want to drive around in a Mercedes at the expense of the rest of the taxpayers. This was no oversight by the Government. It was understood perfectly well by the Government and, to the extent that this tax deters those who provide or have provided these self-indulgences to senior executives from continuing to do so, it is a good thing. Executives can drive around in Holdens; they do not have to have Mercedes, Bentleys or Rolls-Royces. I do not see, the Government does not see and, I gather, the Australian Democrats do not see, any reason at all why the rest of the taxpayers should subsidise that self-indulgence. But in this case the matter goes a little beyond that. The Opposition, which purports to be concerned about sound and healthy economic growth, is on about subsidising through the tax system the self-indulgence of senior executives who want to drive around in Rolls-Royces and Mercedes at public expense-vehicles which, what is more, are imported.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. The Minister is gravely misrepresenting the point that I made and refusing to answer the question. The point I made, quite clearly, is that the present income tax law does not allow a deduction for a such a vehicle.
—Senator Messner, that is not a point of order.
—I thought you were a free trader, not a protectionist.

—It is not a question of protection. I do lean towards the free market, and by definition the free market precludes the use of the tax system and tax subsidies to encourage companies to provide luxury motor vehicles for their senior executives. The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill is aimed with the double purpose of ending that sort of self indulgence at the expense of the rest of the community and raising additional revenue to finance the tax cuts. Since Senator Messner has raised this issue, I say that on most occasions executives can travel in Holdens, Falcons or even small cars, just as well as they can travel in Mercedes and Rolls-Royces. In other words, there is zero contribution to a healthy economy from the use of a Rolls-Royce or a Mercedes where a cheaper vehicle would do. There is the additional problem, of course, that since those vehicles are imported, to the degree that companies are deterred from buying Rolls-Royces and Mercedes, the current account deficit will be closed. The Opposition is in favour, firstly, of continuing through the tax system the subsidisation of status symbols for senior executives which make absolutely no contribution to economic product and, simultaneously, exacerbating the current account deficit and denying the revenue, or a portion of the revenue, that is needed to finance tax cuts for taxpayers in general.

—I rise merely to deny the assertion by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). He has failed to address the very point that I raised. The fact is that tax deductions are not available to companies in the circumstances that he outlined, and he should realise that. We are asking the Government to explain why it is that, in the circumstances where no tax deduction is available-it does not apply only to motor cars; it applies in many other circumstances-it seeks to impose a fringe benefits tax as well; in other words, the double whammy. That explanation is not forthcoming from the Minister.

—I just want to put a very simple question about a farmer who drives his ute to town to pick up a piece of machinery and at the same time his wife goes along and does the shopping. Is that private use or farm use?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that specific case it is farm use. I am not sure about commercial vehicles. The definition of a commercial vehicle is probably dependent on its rated carrying capacity.
—It is one tonne.

—A vehicle with a capacity of below one tonne is classified as a passenger vehicle and vehicles with a capacity of over one tonne are classified as commercials. Anyway, no matter what the capacity of the utility, in those circumstances it would be business use. That relates to the answer I gave earlier, that either one-third of the vehicle's use will be deemed to be business use or, if the farmer concerned chooses to keep a log book or substantiate-the term used by the Australian Taxation Office-he will get an allowance for business use greater than one-third of the total use if in fact the business use is more than one-third.

That the clause, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —These clauses relate to the Government's intention to tax fringe benefits on motor vehicles. I make the point again that this is an employment-destroying tax which clearly will lead to the loss of jobs in the South Australian car industry which, of course, obviously will have an indirect impact on industries in other States as well which are providing materials and components for the motor car industry. I instance the effect on New South Wales because the steel industry, based in Port Kembla and Newcastle, manufacturing sheet metal for the motor vehicle industry, anticipates a fall in its production of that product for the car industry of some 20 per cent this year. Quite clearly, the impact of this Government's fringe benefits tax will have very significant direct effects on motor cars not only produced in South Australia but also in other parts of the Commonwealth. All these things can only be described as job destroying.

SPEECH.PARA: One wonders why the Government continues to persist with this measure especially in the light of the Australian Democrats seeking to move some ameliorating measures in this regard, but nowhere near enough, of course. Clearly, this is the reason why members of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia stand opposed to the measure and why we, when elected to government, will be in a position to repeal this job-destroying tax measure. I think the issues in respect of motor vehicles were aired very strongly in debate prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner. As such, I will not seek again to put before this chamber the matters that we discussed at that stage. However, I indicate again the absolutely categorical opposition of the Liberal and National parties to this tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise only because we have heard from Senator Messner precisely the same comments that he made on the motor car industry before the suspension of the sitting for dinner. I was hoping that we could have got on with the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill. Let me reiterate that the amendments that have been moved, which were passed just before the suspension of the sitting, will cost the Government $200m worth of revenue and are very substantial amendments. As such, the impact on the car industry in South Australia, as in other States, will not be severe at all. In fact, with these amendments the four automotive manufacturers have stated publicly that they believe that the fringe benefits tax, in its present form, will have a minimal effect on employment as far as the motor industry is concerned. That is also the position of the motor car unions, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the South Australian Government and the New South Wales Government. So it would seem to me that the Opposition should at least be prepared to concede that something positive has been done in regard to the tax as it applies to the car industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the clauses stand as printed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 14 to 19-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clauses 14 to 19 relate to the fringe benefits tax being applied to loans; that is to say, if concessional interest rate loans are made by companies, financiers, banks or insurance companies to their employees the employers will be forced under this legislation, if it passes the Parliament, to pay a fringe benefits tax at the rate of 49 per cent on the differential rate of the interest rate paid in respect of that loan compared with the lowest rate available for a housing loan purchase from the Commonwealth Bank.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of points that we would like to bring out in the course of this debate. Firstly, I acknowledge that the Government has included in the Bill a provision whereby the waiver of debts will also be made subject to the fringe benefits tax. That was not announced by the Government in the initial proposals of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in September last year. We have had no explanation as to why it has been included but, clearly, it is in the same area of benefit as loans and, consequently, we can see the logic of the position. But that does not mean that we accept it. As I indicated earlier, we will be opposing the clauses now under discussion and will divide on the matter.

The first matter I bring to the attention of the Minister for Finance is the situation of small businesses. It could also apply to trusts by which small businessmen undertake their business operations. These small businessmen employ about half the working population of Australia. In the situation that quite often does pertain, it is possible that small businessmen operating in that way will make loans to directors of the company or to employees at a low interest or even interest free. This sometimes occurs even though the person to whom the loan is made is not necessarily an active employee of the company. For instance, he or she may be a director of the company and may be in receipt of only very low levels of director's fees.

I would like to distinguish between that case and another where a person who is the beneficiary of an interest free loan or a low interest loan is in fact a director of the company but is not in receipt, nor has he ever been in receipt, of any income as a result of being a director of that company. This can arise in many ways. It is quite possible that companies that do operate in the way that I have just described have no income from which to pay any tax in the nature of a fringe benefits tax. Frequently they are just holding companies which own farming properties or other businesses and have been established in that way in order to establish a form of limitation of legal liability in the event of loss of the property which is the subject of ownership either through bankruptcy or through negligence suits and professional indemnity cases.

Those situations are quite legitimate and obviously do come into existence as a result of motives which individuals have other than purely tax dodging, which Senator Walsh referred to earlier. In other words, there are legitimate commercial reasons why people establish their businesses in that fashion and we do end up with loans being made to people in the circumstances I have outlined. Given that such companies have no real income or very little and certainly very little cash flow, can the Minister point out to us how the companies will be able to pay the fringe benefits tax, if it is applicable? I would like to hear from him as to whether the circumstances that I have outlined apply to small businessmen operating in companies such as the ones I have described.

On the broader issue of bank employees and members of the staff of insurance companies, building societies, merchant banks and other financial institutions being in receipt of loans from their employers at concessional rates, the question arises as to whether this legislation will retrospectively affect their employers. Many of the loans that are in existence for employees in that situation have been in existence for very many years-30 years in many cases. The Government seeks to apply a fringe benefits tax to that concessional rate of interest. I ask the Minister, firstly, whether such retrospectivity as is now included in this legislation applies to loans that are currently in existence. Is my understanding wrong in that case?

Furthermore, the Government has recognised in other parts of this Bill that goods and services which are provided to employees by employers are allowed a 25 per cent discount before the fringe benefits tax will apply to those goods and services. This applies to an employee at David Jones who can buy a suit from his employer at a discounted rate because he is a member of the staff of that company. As I read the Bill, the discount of 25 per cent in those circumstances does not apply to loans in this situation. There seems to be a discrimination here as well. Not only is there retrospectivity, but also there is discrimination in that people can get a discount for the purchase of goods and services, but no such discount is applicable for people who are borrowing money to buy the most important possession of their lives-their own house. That seems to be incongruous. I do not understand why the Government does not allow a discount in those circumstances. Clearly, those kinds of anomalies will create more hardship for operators in this area. As we pointed out earlier in the debate, if it is the Government's intention to push people, that is employers, to cash up benefits, clearly the impact of these measures will eventually be upon the lower income employees who are obtaining this kind of fringe benefit from their employer. The effect of these measures will be quite significant over time, but for now I would appreciate the Minister's comments on the questions I have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I heard Senator Messner correctly, he was postulating that a holding company which had no assets and no income might have granted a housing loan to one of its directors. If that is so, it seems to me like a pretty shonky arrangement. Why is a holding company with no assets and no income granting a housing loan to one of its directors? It sounds almost as shonky as another case that I can remember a few years ago concerning somebody who, according to the records of the Corporate Affairs Commission of New South Wales, was a director of a company called Mundroola and was living in a house, also called Mundroola, owned by the company. He had been living in that house and had been a director, according to what the Corporate Affairs Commission records showed, from 1974 to 1981. Under those circumstances either that director was obliged to include in his personal tax return, as imputed income for a company-occupied house, some notional rent, or alternatively, the company was required to include in its company taxation return the rent received from the director-tenant of the company-owned house. The tenant concerned at the time was the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia. Very conveniently in 1981 a letter of resignation became public which was dated 1974. The ink was still wet. In other words, the Chief Justice of Australia at that time was in a situation, by any prima facie grounds of evidence, in which he was a tax evader. To get himself around that problem he became a forger. The sort of case that Senator Messner was presenting seems to me to be about as shonky as that particular arrangement. If somebody, in an arrangement as shonky as that, is in some way caught up by this law, it seems to me a further demonstration of why we need a law such as this.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of a 25 per cent discount on purchases by employees of companies not applying to loans is, according to my information, correct. The discount of up to 25 per cent on purchases is a concession. It is a concession that has been offered for two reasons: Firstly, because the sort of people who are affected by it are `little' people; secondly, given that the absolute amounts involved are likely to be so small it is really not worth pursuing administratively. It is a very different case if one were to offer a 25 per cent discount on a housing loan. Let us take a housing loan of $50,000 at present interest rates. A 25 per cent discount on that is, in round figures, $2,000 a year. A fringe benefit of $2,000 a year is vastly in excess of the sort of small benefit which the employee of David Jones, Grace Bros, Woolworths or of such firms as those gets. So, yes, there is a concession to the `small' people which has not been extended to those who are into fringe benefits in a big way.

The final point I want to make is that where such a loan is in existence the tax will apply only prospectively, that is to the extent that there is an interest concession which has a value in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —But does it apply to existing loans?

—Yes, but only on prospective interest. So, Senator Messner wants to make a case that is retrospective; I suppose people can believe whatever they want to believe, and Senator Messner can believe what he wants to believe. But on any rational assessment it is just not so; the tax is not retrospective. If it applies at all it applies only to the value of the interest concession which will accrue prospectively.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tirade of the Minister for Finance is typical of him and is not something to which I was seeking a reply. I was seeking an answer to a technical point that I am trying to establish. Because of the breadth of the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 and the way it defines an employee as being a person who is either a past employee, a current employee, or a future employee, loans could inevitably go on forever. I will give the Senate an instance of the sort of situation that could occur. A young man at the age of 16 or 17 years of age is employed by his father as a greengrocer. He works part time after school. For the purposes of the legislation, it seems to me that he becomes an employee. At a later stage in his life he may marry at, let us say age 24 and his parents, in the normal way that parents do, may decide to give him a loan at a reasonable family arrangement, at concessional rate of interest or even interest free, to purchase a home for his new family. Because of the breadth of the situation and the definition in the Bill it seems to me that that loan would become chargeable and liable to fringe benefits tax. I am trying to establish whether part time employees in that situation are of the kind that will be caught by the Government's legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: By extension, I was also trying to find out from the Minister whether or not in the circumstances of small proprietary companies where loans are made to directors-maybe the son, in the case I have just mentioned, had been a director of the company at some time during his life, in the past or even perhaps at some time in the future-the directors would then be caught for the fringe benefits tax in any circumstances that might apply right throughout their lifetime? I would also like to know whether such a person would be classed as an employee if that person is a director even though he receives no remuneration. Maybe he never received any remuneration from the company. If he did receive some remuneration, even of a small nature, perhaps a nominal sum for being a director of that company, does he then find himself caught and defined as an employee, be it past, current or future, for the purposes of the application of the fringe benefits tax?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the question about the director who received no payment as Senator Messner said, one can get payment in various ways. One can get payments above the table as a wage or a salary or a directors fee, or one can get payments below the table in the form of having fees paid to Geelong Grammar School for one's children, or to the Melbourne Club for membership or for a Rolls-Royce or a Mercedes Benz. If a director received income in cash for services as a director or whether he receives in the ways I have mentioned, is not, in principle in my view, at all relevant. The answer to the question is: If the person concerned were a director, and therefore deemed to be an employee of a company, and received no income in cash for those services, but received income in kind, that would be, until such time as it is cashed out, taxable in the hands of the company. And so it ought to be, because this is precisely what this legislation is aimed at; at closing off rorts such as that where people who are company directors can receive very substantial remuneration in kind on which nobody pays any tax. That is what this legislation is aimed at.

SPEECH.PARA: I will cite again the former High Court judge who was occupying a company house-I have only circumstantial evidence on this, of course, and section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act prevents me from obtaining anything more substantial-on which presumably he was paying no rent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. On the question of relevance, the point we are on is loans being paid to employees.
—No. I am explaining the rort.
—There is a point of order being raised, Minister.

—This question is one of relevance. It appears to me that the Minister is being totally irrelevant. We are dealing with loans and there are questions of interest to the people of Australia about the interpretation of this legislation which need to be answered. I hope that the Minister will take a more constructive attitude to the debate.
—There is no point of order.

—I was answering Senator Messner's question. He raised a question about directors not receiving any income in cash but receiving income in kind which clearly includes people who were receiving housing loans at concessional rates of interest. The case to which I referred is highly relevant, because the prima facie evidence shows that the Chief Justice of Australia between 1974 and 1981 was a tax evader. When so much information was thrown out that would have established him as a tax evader to the Commissioner of Taxation, he became a forger to get himself off the hook. Unfortunately he got away with it. Once this Bill becomes law, people will not be able to do that any more because, if somebody in that position is occupying a company house without paying any rent, the company will be charged tax on the rent equivalent.

SPEECH.PARA: The other question of fact concerned a past employee who continued to receive a fringe benefit. If someone who has been an employee and in that capacity received a concessional loan from the company-he is no longer an employee of the company but continues to receive the benefits of that concessional loan-I am advised that the answer is that the company will be charged the fringe benefits tax accordingly. The company, unless it is tied up in a watertight contract, would have the option, I suppose, of calling in the loan. If Senator Messner is going to suggest, as his comments imply, that there is something unduly harsh about that, I think we need to look at the reason why the company gave the employee the concessional loan in the first place. It seems to me very clear that the reason was that the company was paying that employee income in kind. The whole trust of this Bill is directed against income being paid in kind free of tax.

The question of children was also raised. The recurrent theme, which I understand was also raised in the House of Representatives, is the assertion that tax will be imposed on parents who employ their children. It is said that the bedrooms of children on a farm, the meals they eat, the birthday presents they receive and so on will be taxed. This is also said about children employed in small businesses-for example, a plumber who has an apprentice son; perhaps these days a plumber can have an apprentice daughter. The fact is that a benefit is taxable only if received in respect of employment. The examples above are clearly situations where the benefit is given out of the ordinary family relationships and parental responsibilities to their children. It is not related to employment and will not be taxed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like the Minister to clarify a point in relation to rural areas. The Minister would know that often a son will follow in his father's footsteps and work on the family property. What will be the position if the son lives within the family home while being employed by his parents? Will his board be calculated as a fringe benefit as he is a full employee of the father in that instance? Will the meal made by his mother and the accommodation supplied by his father as a full employee of the parents be taken to be board of the type that is stipulated in the little lilac book?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In general, the answer is no, it would not be taxable for somebody who is the child of, to take Senator Walters's case, a farmer and who is living in the family home. Apart from the question of parental relationship, responsibility or whatever, there is also in principle, of course, a sound reason for this. In a case where, let us say, a 16- or 17-year-old is working on a farm and still living in the family home on the farm, neither the provisions nor the accommodation which the parent is supplying to the child are tax deductible to the parent-I will lodge one caveat there and add something to it later-because in general personal housing is not tax deductible nor is household expenditure on food and whatever. The situation is, though, of course, quite different when somebody who is an employee at arm's length, if you like, is living in a house provided by the employer on which the employer is able to and has claimed deductions from the employer's taxable income related to the cost of providing and maintaining the house.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the caveat that I referred to. Of course, I do not hear the National Farmers Federation talking too much about this, for pretty obvious reasons. In a farm situation the personal residence is tied to the farm and, if there is a mortgage on the farm, the interest payments on that mortgage are deductible from taxable income even though in a puristic sense not all of them ought to be if full equality of treatment were to be provided. If the farm has on it a house which is used as a residence by the owner, the owner is in a de facto way, if there is a mortgage, claiming a deduction from taxable income for interest payments on that house. That, of course, is a concession. It can be a major concession. It is one I do not hear very much about; nevertheless, it exists. I guess, given that we live in a world that is less than purist and given the obvious complications of disentangling whether the mortgage is on the house or the farm, even though under normal circumstances the two are sold together, it is not worth pursing. Nevertheless, it is a windfall gain to a number of people who are engaged in agriculture.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister a question subsequent to what he has just been saying. Am I to understand that if a farmer and his wife have two young men living in the farm house, both working on the farm, and one is related by blood and the other is not, there will be a fringe benefit payable on the accommodation of the one who is not related by blood but there will be no fringe benefit payable on the one related by blood?

—Senator Newman used the term `blood relation'. I am not sure how far one can extend that, so I will be a bit guarded in my answer. But if it were a direct member of the family-as direct as, say, a sibling or an offspring-as I understand it, the answer is no, that would not be assessable; nor, probably, would it be if it were, say, an adopted child who had no identifiable genetic relationship with the provider. If I am wrong about this, I trust the officials will correct me. I have not had time to consult them. If, on the other hand, the person still living in the house is not an identifiable relation in any way and is being provided with meals and accommodation-and I believe there is still some provision in the farm workers award allowing an employer to deduct from the wages of that employee some allowance for board and lodging-the difference between whatever deduction is made and the cost of providing the board and accommodation would be taxable as a fringe benefits tax, with the proviso that account would be taken of whether an employer could demonstrate that in fact the cost was more than that. However, that is rather complicated and I think that perhaps I had better give the honourable senator an answer in writing. I think the answer in general is that, if employees are not necessarily blood relations but members of the family in the sort of way I have defined it, there would be no tax applied; but if they were clearly not identifiable with the family in any way, it would be.
—I would just like to ask the Minister whether there is a provision in this Bill for that distinction.
—I am advised that only part of what I said was correct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no provision in clause 14 for an employer to waive a debt because of financial hardship of the employee. I give an example of this which will get the Minister for Finance (Mr Walsh) out of the Mercedes and Rolls-Royces and back into the relationship between an employer and employees on a farm, as the Minister would have remembered back in his time, when the employer may have given a loan to an employee on a reasonable rate of income, at the ordinary rate of interest, not the concessional rate. If, because of the employee's hardship, he cannot repay the loan and the employer waives the repayment of the loan, there does not seem to be anything in clause 14 to clarify that. I think it would be rather hard on some of the bona fide employees who have received an ordinary loan, not a concessional loan.

SPEECH.PARA: The wording in clause 16 is bad because, if one reads it and is unaware of what is stated in other parts of the Bill in terms of the provider, one could incorrectly, but most probably understandably, make the assumption that anyone who makes a loan to another person would be liable for fringe benefits tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last point, as I understand it, is quite wrong because there has to be an employer-employee relationship before a loan would become taxable. It is certainly incorrect to say that anyone who makes a loan on concessional terms to anyone else is liable to pay such a tax, because there must be an employer-employee relationship for it to apply.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of clause 14, it is conceivable that the circumstances Senator Brownhill set out could happen, but it is also necessary to have a clause such as that to close off a potential loophole whereby an employer could grant, in lieu of wages or salary income, a highly concessional loan. If an employer comes to an arrangement with an employee to pay the employee $10,000 in salary and to give him a $20,000 loan, then 12 months later the employee says that he is in a bit of a financial jam and cannot repay the loan, the employer could write it off. If we allow that sort of thing to happen, it would clearly open up a loophole which could undermine the whole purpose of closing off the concessional loans.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the bona fide loan, where it goes on for 10 years?
—The only problem there is that it is a bit hard to define what is bona fide.

—I return to this point because it is critical that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) understands exactly what the Opposition is trying to put to him so that we can get some clear statement on how the new tax will apply. I refer again to the example I gave earlier, which has been mentioned by my colleagues as well. Where a 16-year-old son of a greengrocer works part time in the shop and receives a part time salary, as I understand it, within the meaning of `employment' in the Bill he is an employee. At some future time, given that he finished that employment, got some other job with some other employer at the age of 23 or 24, then subsequently decided to marry, if a loan is made by his father, as I read this Bill, he is defined as an employee because he is a past employee of his father. Even if we look at it the other way around-that he may be a future employee-he would be caught because the definition includes future employees as well. We are trying to get this point clear. Is a person in that situation defined as an employee of his employer and is fringe benefits tax applicable?
—I am advised that the answer to that is no because the benefit, although hypothetical, was not given in respect of that employment.

—In relation to the question I asked, which was picked up later by Senator Newman, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) said that he was partly right. Can the Minister tell me the difference, because I cannot find anywhere in the Bill anything which says that an employee who is a member of the family will not be charged fringe benefits tax on board, whereas another employee who is not a member of the family will incur fringe benefits tax on the board. Can the Minister explain where that is laid out clearly in the Bill? I have had a chat to a member of the House of Representatives who said that a different description entirely was given in the other place and I would like to know who is right, the Minister or the Treasurer (Mr Keating).
—The benefit--
—Does it make any difference if it is the subject of an award?

—It is not a question of a reward, it is a question of whether the benefit was provided because of the employer-employee relationship. The general ruling would be, particularly in the case of a minor who was employed and was living in the parental home, that the benefit was not given because of the employer-employee relationship but because of the family relationship. Senator Newman asked whether the person had to be a blood relative. The answer to that would have to be no because an adopted child is not a blood relative.
—I don't think she was being that subtle.

—She used the term `blood relative'. The critical determining factor is whether the benefit was provided because of an employer-employee relationship of a family relationship. I guess it is a matter of common sense. It may not always be easy to distinguish between the two, as it is not easy in many matters of taxation law, but if Senator Walters wants something definite from the Commissioner of Taxation, I will get it in writing.

—It is very simple. A 20-year-old lad is the son of a farmer and is a full time employee of that farmer. If he were not employed by his father he would be working elsewhere and would not be living on the property. He is living in his family home because he is not married and he is a full time employee. Let us make him 23 years old, so we will not call him a minor. His mother cooks his meals and his father supplies the bedroom. Will that lad's board be calculated in the fringe benefits tax? It could not be clearer.

—There is one omission from Senator Walters's hypothetical case. The same young man could be living at home and employed in a nearby town, in which case the board would not be counted. If he were employed on the farm and had been living in the same house he had lived in since childhood, the answer is that the board would not be counted. While I am on this question, just in case anybody in outback Queensland has been listening to the usual heap of nonsense, rubbish and misrepresentations that have been pouring out from members of the Country Party, or the National Party as it calls itself these days, who I understand have been peddling this myth in a very big way in Queensland in particular but also in New South Wales, the answer is that what they are saying is not true.

—Can the Minister tell me where in the Bill we find that the answer is no because the Bill states that if he is an employee the fringe benefits tax does apply. It does not state that if the employee happens to be the son or daughter of the employer he or she is not charged board even if he or she has lived in the home since birth. Can the Minister explain to me where the Bill makes allowance for a son or daughter not to be charged board when they are full time employees, but someone who is not related must be charged board?

—The answer appears in the definitions. Since Senator Walters purports to be such an expert on these matters, it is a pity she has not looked at the Bill properly. Incidentally, I do not pretend to have done that. I have been occupied by one or two other things. But if she looks at page 105, dealing with definitions, at line 12 she will find the words `fringe benefit' and at line 25 `in respect of the employment of the employee'. I will not quote the entire definition, but it sets out what I have been saying; that is, that it depends on whether the benefit is received because of the employee-employer relationship or for some other reason.

—That does not clarify it at all. Quite frankly, in the situation I have suggested to the Minister, the child of the employer is a full time employee. If he were not a full time employee, he would not be residing in the family home. He would, by necessity--
—Not by necessity at all.

—Not by necessity, but it is because on this occasion he is a full time employee of the farm that he is residing in the family home. I have read the definition to which the Minister referred very quickly and it has nothing to do with relationships. It has to do only with the employee receiving board because he is an employee. Obviously, in the instance I gave, he is receiving the board as an employee. If he were not, his father would have to employ someone else. That person would obviously board there, too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how long we have to go on with this, but the critical line is `in respect of the employment of the employee'. I do not know how many times one has to say these things. The Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: `fringe benefit', in relation to an employee, in relation to the employer of the employee, . . . means a benefit-
in respect of the employment of the employee . . .

What Senator Walters is saying is that it is a benefit in respect of his being a member of the family and not an employee. If she is too thick to understand it, it is my misfortune, but it is not my fault.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the fact that the Minister seems to have difficulty in finding his way around the Bill, I draw his attention in considering this matter to page 101 where the definitions of `employee' and `employment' are clearly set out. It may help the Minister in deciding whether that blood relation or son of the employer is an employee if I read the definition to him. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: `employee' means-
(a) a current employee;
(b) a future employee; or
(c) a former employee;
There is no limitation on that. It does not say `except where he happens to be a member of the family or is boarding there in another capacity'. The definition of `employment' reads:

. . . in relation to a person, includes the holding of any office or appointment, the performance of any functions or duties, the engaging in of any work, or the doing of any acts or things that results, will result or has resulted in the person being treated as an employee;

I imagine that means that the father, acting as employer, will say: `I want you down at the cattle yards at 7 o'clock and I want you to take the stock into the sale yards'. I imagine that that is his being treated as an employee. Is the provision of his accommodation also in the realms of his capacity as an employee? I would like the Minister, having had the benefit of that walk through the definitions, to give us a more detailed answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the benefit to be relevant it must be paid to an employee and because of the relationship as an employee and not something else. If Senator Newman is going to object to this Bill being passed, I would like to ask her how the hell she thinks the taxpayers of Australia will pay her doubly superannuated husband if we cannot collect some revenue from somebody?

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I take a point of order. I feel that the Minister should also make that statement to all the women in the Public Service who are eligible for their husband's superannuation benefits. They will be glad to know he is against that.
—There is no point of order.

—The comments of the Minister are absolutely outrageous. I hope he will withdraw that. It is quite clear that the Minister is loosing his cool because quite clearly he cannot answer the questions that are being put to him by the Opposition. I must say that the question last put to him by Senator Newman was a very clear and a precise point that we are trying to get at and which homes in on the difficulty of this legislation. I reiterate-I do not think I can do it as well as Senator Newman-that the point simply is that at page 101, in regard to the definition of `employee', he or she is defined as a current employee, a future employee or a former employee. When we turn to the definition which the Minister spoke of earlier, it refers to employment of an employee. The employee is a current, former or a future employee. If the legislation contains such a definition, which is so all embracing, how can the Minister say that a person will not be liable for the fringe benefits tax in the situation that we have been trying to outline?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to put it in monosyllables, but since it is not written in monosyllables, I cannot do so. Page 105, line 25, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: in respect of the employment of the employee . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to pose a hypothetical question to the Minister. I take the case of two sons who have been working on a smallish property that will sustain a one family income. The father gives a son-one son-a loan to buy another property. The son has been employed by the father. He marries and the property will not sustain an income for two people. Is that loan now subject to the fringe benefits tax?

—Mr Temporary Chairman, on a point of order: I am beginning to wonder whether hypothetical questions will be thrown at the Minister all night. There would seem to be no end to this. I ask you, Mr Temporary Chairman, whether it would not be more appropriate for this very esoteric or hypothetical question to be put in writing so that an expert opinion can be gained.
—There is no point of order.
—Senator Boswell has not said whether the loan was at a concessional rate of interest. If it was not at a concessional rate of interest--
—No, it is at a concessional rate.
