TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to draw attention to a report which, in the normal course of events, would have been tabled in the Senate, but, due to a decision of this House that Government Business should take priority, the report will not be discussed in this session. I did not want to miss the opportunity to speak on it. The report is the report of the Aboriginal Women's Task Force, entitled `Women's business', and is from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet through the Office of the Status of Women. I begin by commending this report to anyone with any interest in Aboriginal affairs and in particular in the concerns facing Aboriginal women. It is an excellent report and it includes the history of the way in which governments, Federal, State and territorial, have dealt with the Aboriginal people since the arrival of white settlement in this country. As an introductory historical document-the report makes no claims to being conclusive-it is invaluable and I suggest that any number of people in our community might do well to read a copy of the report if for no other reason than to learn the Aboriginal history contained therein. It could be said that this is a history of white failure of the Aboriginal people over almost 200 years of white settlement in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The report should also be commended for the comprehensiveness of its coverage not only in the areas addressed, but also in the areas of Australia that were visited by the Task Force. The map on page XII shows the many communities which the Task Force visited. The map of Australia was very well covered judging by all the dots that are shown. I also commend the many people involved in the Aboriginal Women's Task Force, particularly in the campaign to get a task force established in the first place, and that has a long history which is neatly documented in this report. It includes a small historical report of the struggle of Aboriginal women and the efforts they have made to get a formal hearing and acceptance by government. That campaign started in the years of the Fraser Government and was completed under this Government which, in effect, went ahead and comprehensively sponsored the Aboriginal Women's Task Force. I believe the Government is pleased to receive this report and its recommendations.
There is one particular chapter which is worthy of consideration here-perhaps we should never forget it. On page 22 of the report the following is written:

After 197 years of white settlement, this is the statistical profile of the descendants of the people who have lived in this country for at least 40,000 years: an infant mortality rate three or four times greater than that of all Australians; life expectancy about 20 years less than that of all Australians; a median family income slightly more than half of that of other Australians; an unemployment rate that has tripled since 1971 to be four times that of other Australians; a disproportionate number of uneducated, under-educated and imprisoned. Then there is the fact that they continue to be victims of an astonishing legal fiction-that the land when Captain Cook `discovered' it was `terra nullius', no-one's land.

That paragraph and the statistical information there is elaborated upon in the back of the report in one of the many comprehensive appendices. Apart from recommending that everybody look at this section, I wish to allude particularly to one point-the figures on infant mortality rates. Some people might worry that these figures are out of date. Indeed they are not; they take us up to 1982. The way in which infant mortality is recorded is by the number of deaths per 1,000 births. In 1976 in Queensland 65.9 Aboriginal children died per 1,000 births. That figure had fallen to 23.6 in 1982. In the Northern Territory in 1976 was 52.8 and this had fallen to 38.3 in 1982. Just again for the record, more than 38 Aboriginal babies per 1,000 births die within the first year of their life.

That figure needs to be compared with the overall mortality figure for Australians in general. That mortality rate is 10.3 per 1,000 live births, compared with 38.3 for Northern Territory Aboriginal infants. We must remember that the 10.3 figure for live births in Australia actually includes that horrifically high Aboriginal figure. Therefore, a white baby's chances of survival are more than four times that of an Aboriginal baby. To put it in reverse, an Aboriginal baby born in the Northern Territory is four times more likely to die before its first birthday than a non-Aboriginal. If nothing else this whole report is worth while for recalling to the Senate that quite horrific statistic. That has happened in a country which has boasted the lowest or the near lowest infant mortality figure for at least the past 20 years or so. Australia's figure is very low-a matter of real pride-but we still know that that figure hides a shockingly high Aboriginal neo-natal mortality rate. That is not the principal point in the report but it is one that cannot be missed in looking at this very comprehensive study of all the issues facing Aboriginal women.

The question of Aboriginal women's health is a particular matter that is raised but the terms of reference for the Task Force were far greater than that. They included land rights, the right to education, housing and so on. However, that matter of health stands out. A society which copes so comprehensively with health matters for its urban and white population should seriously address these problems when they relate to its Aboriginal population. We do not need any magic potions to reduce the mortality rate among Aboriginal people; we need accessible and ordinary health care-the management of gastro-enteritis, of childhood infections, of adequate ante-natal care and of the diet of mothers. These are very simple, common sense matters of basic general health. As a priority we should insist on quickly addressing such problems. I would not like this to be the only issue that is addressed as a result of this report but it is certainly an important one.

The recommendations are comprehensive and housing is very high on the priority list. It is not surprising that that should be so, given the report's description of the housing provisions for Aboriginal people. The area of education again produces a comprehensive series of recommendations as do health and, the question of fostering and adoption, which is a matter of importance for Aboriginal people who are concerned with the difficulties faced as a result of white adoption of Aboriginal children and the resulting possibility of the loss of Aboriginal culture to those children. Any number of illustrations, which we could all cite, point to why this was one of the terms of reference which was so comprehensively addressed in this report. The problems of employment, crime, punishment, legal aid, land rights and community services are all addressed. The report points out what some of us are already aware of, that one cannot expect to look at any one aspect of Aboriginal women's concerns without looking at the whole of the problems that I have just cited. All of those things intertwine both in cause and effect and the report goes to a request, in effect, for government to address the recommendations in the comprehensive way proposed in the report.

I most seriously recommend this report to the Senate. I think it is, if nothing else, an excellent reference but, more importantly, I think it calls to our attention the needs of Aboriginal women. The point raised in the report that Aboriginal women were finally spoken to and had the opportunity to make their voice heard is a very significant one. Again, the report quotes Aboriginal women who have said: `We have not been asked much before, but even when we were it was white people asking us and we were shy and felt unable to answer. We are pleased to be able to make our comments because we are telling other black women, and they can take our message'. There is a sense in which this report appreciates that dimension of Aboriginal women and the fact that they are reticent or shy to put their case. The task force as it was established has been able to meet with and hear from those women and take into account all those things that Aboriginal women around Australia have said. I think it is an excellent report. I congratulate those people who produced it, and I will be interested to hear the Government's response to it.

After a couple of weeks, inquiries were made as to why the service had stopped, and I was told that it was because of a shortage of flowers. This seems fair and equitable. If there is a shortage of flowers, naturally the supply of cut flowers to senators and members officers will stop. I had noticed, however, that the shortage was not of such extreme proportions as to prevent Joint House offices at the end of the Senate transport corridor being adequately supplied with flowers. I say `offices' to indicate that I am not simply referring to the office of the Secretary to the Joint House Department but to the entire collection of offices at the end of the Senate corridor. Being new, and having the reticence in a number of areas that all new people have, I decided to say nothing, thinking it was better to work out the system before making a comment.

Before I go on, I do not wish to be seen as doing a disservice to the Joint House Department. There is the possibility that all of the flowers in that area came from a private garden, or that the officers did a whip round for petty cash and sent someone off to the florist. All the flowers were the same. They all came from the same place, or they appeared to be of the same nature, and they had a remarkable similarity to those flowers in the garden. Nonetheless, if they came from a private garden or if the officers did a whip-around and supplied themselves in time of shortage and need, good luck to them and I withdraw any inference that someone may draw from the comments that I have made thus far.

Time passed on and upon a visit to the photostat machine at the end of the Senate transport corridor I noticed a large tin of roses-several dozen in fact-in the little Joint House office that used to be used to accommodate the photostat machine, which, burgeoning bureaucracy being what it is these days, is now out in the corridor. Being naturally blessed, or inflicted, depending on which way one likes to look at it, with a loud voice, I commented on how lovely the roses were and asked whether I could have a few of them, because it was a big tin, to take to my office and put in the vase that had been supplied for me. With frightening speed-I use that word advisedly-someone came out of the Joint House Office, someone now known to me as the secretary to the Secretary to the Joint House Department. It was clearly explained to me that I could not have any of those flowers; they were for the Joint House Department. I could look, but not touch.

Like a child, I accepted the comments and returned to my duties, not thinking much of it. But when this year's session began the shortage of flowers did not appear to have gone away. Further inquiries were made, including a telephone call by me to the Joint House Secretary, as I wished now to complain. Joint House had flowers and I did not. The secretary to the Secretary inquired as to the subject matter I wanted to raise with the Secretary. I said, quite simply, `flowers'. When pressed, I indicated that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Pressed flowers?

—When I was pressed as to the further nature of the subject I wished to raise, I indicated that it was the lack thereof. Once again, the shortage excuse was drummed up. This shortage was now of disastrous proportions. We had moved from October and were now in April. Either a plague of locusts had eaten all the flowers between October and April, a period of seven months, or something else had happened. With the brazenness that a second-year junior back bencher acquires, I spoke out this time and pointed out that the shortage did not appear to me to be of such disastrous proportions as to deprive the Joint House offices of these flowers.

SPEECH.PARA: I got what I thought and still think was a fairly stunning response. With some surprise in the voice of the speaker on the other end of the phone, I was told almost: `Well, of course; the Secretary to the Joint House Department is more important than any senator or member'. I sort of chuckled in some disbelief and pointed out that as I did not as readily come to the same conclusion, I would still like to catch up with the Secretary to the Joint House Department. In fact, I do not come to that conclusion at all. The secretary to the Secretary told me that she would speak to the gardener. I was at a loss to see why this disastrous shortage of flowers would suddenly be the gardener's fault. I do not know whose fault it is and I do not wish to draw any inference as to whose fault it is. Nonetheless, half an hour after this conversation, flowers arrived in my room. They were in near full bloom by the end of the week. Not wishing to throw them out when they were in near full bloom, when I departed for my electorate I left them in my room. By the time I returned, they were crisp in the vase. This may say something about the cleaning capacity of the Joint House Department. On the second occasion this year I have returned, having left flowers in perfectly good condition in a vase to find them crisp in the vase exactly where I left them, with the water in a state of odour that can be described only as not very pleasant. Two days later the secretary to the Secretary to the Joint House Department very courteously rang me to advise me that the Secretary was free. I mentioned that I had someone with me and, in fact, I had to do this a couple of times to make it clear that there was no way I was going to the secretary's office then and there just because the Secretary was free.

I understand that the matter of service of cut flowers has been raised at the Joint House committee meetings because, I understand, I am not the only senator who believes that if a service is offered it should be provided or, alternatively, it should not be offered. Other senators have told me the story of a particular senator, I think known to everyone here, who was caught in the garden with a pair of secateurs and figuratively speaking, of course, was pounced on by the gardener. A senator in the garden with secateurs working on the self-supply principle for flowers is not a pleasant sight for a gardener. The gardener came up and exclaimed: `I am supposed to do that'. The senator replied `I know', went on cutting the flowers and took them back to the said senator's office.

I am sure that the point I am making tonight is not lost. It is not a question of whether or not senators should be supplied with flowers. Let me summarise by saying this: As I said before, I do not think the service is a necessary one except for Ministers and Presiding Officers. Secondly, if the service is to be offered it should be provided properly. Thirdly, it is not my belief that senators, members and the Joint House Department all came into being at the same time and the argument of which came first-the chicken or the egg-simply does not apply in the case of those three categories. That fact should be drawn to the attention of those in the Joint House Department who may be of a different view.

I point out that I looked today to confirm whether or not the Joint House Department offices were still amply supplied with flowers. As I went after a certain time this evening, I discovered that all the Joint House Department offices were locked. Staff of the Department had gone home. So I cannot inform the Senate whether those offices are still being supplied with flowers, when I know that I am not and that other senators who have put in a request to make use of the service that is offered in this beautiful leaflet that is sent around are also not being supplied with flowers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words tonight about a complaint I have received from Mr Russell Hancock, a resident of Parramatta in the west of the city of Sydney. Before I do, I wish to follow up something that was said by Senator Vanstone. You will recall, Mr President, the saga of how honourable senators obtained Commander telephone systems. Senator Vanstone may not know but some years ago I became aware that officers of the Joint House Department had Commander telephone systems while honourable senators did not. Rather than making a speech in the Senate on the adjournment debate, I remember that I went to the relevant Estimates Committee hearing and I was able to ask the Joint House Department officers about the merits of Commander telephone systems and whether they had something to offer.
—We will all await Senator Vanstone's examination of the estimates of God knows what at the next session.

—Nevertheless, Joint House Department officers assured me that the Commander telephones did have merit and did have advantages. I then asked whether the officers had those systems themselves. They did indeed. I asked whether Mr President had a Commander telephone. I was told that Mr President did not. I know that within an hour and a half I had an automatic dialling telephone.
—So did I.

—So did Mr President. It is amazing how quickly things move. It may be a good idea for the Joint House Department to realise that it is there to serve us and not vice versa. I come back to Mr Russell Hancock. He has experienced some long running battles with the Commissioner of Taxation and, more recently, with the Commonwealth Reporting Service. I want to raise his problem because he believes he has been the victim of a conspiracy. He has asked me as a senator to lay on the record some of the facts. He says that he has been treated badly by those in authority. Indeed, he seems to have been shown scant respect. If his story is correct, it suggests that Shakespeare's words about the calumny of power may operate here if in fact he has been unable to get the kind of satisfaction that he has sought.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last year or so, I have had some problems in obtaining information from some departments under provisions of the Freedom of Information Act. Owing to a great readiness to use the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, I have discovered that that is the stick sufficient to get information out. Only last week, I sought the release of information concerning possible migration of nazis to Australia. That information was only obtained through using the Freedom of Information Act and putting various other pressures on departments.

Nevertheless, I come back to Mr Hancock. The case he put to me is one which is disturbing. I ask the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) whether she will at least have the matter put before the relevant Minister after I have set it out, because the facts are significant and Mr Hancock may have a complaint. The situation simply is that Mr Hancock sold some shares at the time of the 1970s mining boom. The Taxation Commissioner raised an assessment indicating that the profit on the sale of the shares would be taxable. That became an issue of contention between them. Mr Hancock appealed to the Taxation Board of Review. This appeal was successful and, after negotiations, the tax payable was reduced to a very small amount.

The conduct of this appeal before the Board of Review is the main concern that Mr Hancock has continued to pursue. He maintains, not that the decision was a bad decision, because he won his appeal, but that the transcript of evidence taken by the tribunal was tampered with. So he applied for access to the original tapes to check them against the transcripts which he had received and which purported to be transcripts of the appeal proceedings. He was then told that the tapes had been destroyed in line with normal procedure. As Mr Hancock sought access to the tapes under freedom of information legislation, and as they could not be supplied to him, he was able to seek a hearing before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to find out whether the tapes had really been destroyed and, if so, in what circumstances.

Here is the issue: A citizen says that a transcript which purports to be a transcript of what transpired before the tribunal is in fact not an accurate transcript, so he wants to check it against the tapes. Mr Hancock was able to point to records disposal schedule No. S393 put out by the Australian Archives which identifies the procedures for the erasure of tapes. He and the Commonwealth Reporting Service strongly disagree on the interpretation of that schedule. Mr Hancock claims that the Reporting Service is bound to notify Archives of the destruction of a tape. The Commonwealth Reporting Service claims that it does not destroy used tapes but it merely `bulk erases' them after a set time like two to three months. I suppose that that is not destruction, but it certainly destroys what is on the tapes. For the purposes we are talking about it in fact is destruction.

The Reporting Service says that the written transcription is the master copy and that it does not keep records of the destruction or the erasure of the tapes. This statement is disputed by Mr Hancock, who cites a conversation with a now deceased officer of the Commonwealth Reporting Service, a Mr MacDonald, formerly Principal Reporter of that Service in New South Wales, who told him that a copy of the tape was kept for a longer period than two to three months. That extra copy appears to have been kept by the Taxation Board of Review in Mr Hancock's case.

So here we have a transcript. We have Mr Hancock believing that it is not an accurate transcript. He wants to get the the original tape. He believes a second copy is in existence, and he applies for it. He says that he believes that the master tape was destroyed one or two days after he made an approach to the Ombudsman to see whether he could obtain it from the Taxation Board of Review. That is a bit rough. A person who is just a private citizen goes to the Ombudsman, and the tape in question is immediately destroyed. Mr Hancock has told me that Mr Richardson, the Ombudsman, made a telephone call to the Commonwealth Reporting Service on Monday, 5 May 1980, asking for access to the relevant tape, and the tape was destroyed by erasure on either Tuesday, 6 May or Wednesday, 7 May, according to information alleged by Mr Hancock and presented to me. So that is the story.

Three questions really need to be answered. Was the transcript of Mr Hancock's appearance before the Taxation Board of Review edited so as to change the sense of the actual presentation of the material at that hearing? That is the first question. The second question is: Was a tape of that hearing deliberately destroyed after it became known that Mr Hancock was seeking it through the Ombudsman in order to check it against the transcript he had received? Thirdly, should the Commonwealth Reporting Service notify Archives when it undertakes what it describes as `bulk erasure' of tapes, which really seems to me to be destruction of the material on the tapes? I have an open mind on the matter, but these questions should be answered quite definitely, because some citizens may feel that they have not had due process offered to them.

We have to remember that most transcripts, in the same way as is Hansard, are edited to tidy up language, but they are not supposed to be edited to alter the sense of what has been said. Mr Hancock claims that the sense of what was said at the Board of Review hearing was altered. He is not complaining about tidying up, but about any alteration of sense. He is complaining not only that there was no tape against which he could check the transcript, but also that, when he went to the Ombudsman, he believed the only existing tape was deliberately and immediately destroyed.

I have in my possession extremely detailed records from my constituent which I would gladly make available to Senator Ryan or to departmental officers if it is their desire to get more information, but I have no doubt that they know Mr Hancock and his case quite well. I wonder whether those three questions could be answered and whether the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) or the Treasurer (Mr Keating), depending on whether one goes down the taxation road or the Commonwealth Reporting Service road, could look into the matters and at the three questions I asked and take the appropriate action to make sure that, if another Mr Hancock appears and if another question is raised as to the accuracy of a transcript of a hearing before a board of review, the plaintiff, the person who has actually sought the review, is able to receive speedy and helpful advice and access to the tapes in order to check whether or not what that person said at the review hearing is in fact accurate.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 March 1986 (Hansard, page 970), Senator Walters asked me a number of related questions, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. Senator Walters's questions concerned forestry activities in Tasmania and the conclusion of an agreement between the Commonwealth and Tasmania associated with the Commonwealth's recent decision to renew woodchip export licences for the State.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

The Premier of Tasmania, Mr Gray, forwarded me a signed copy of a proposed Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between our Governments dated 9 January 1986. It is intended that the MOU, along with export licence conditions, will provide the means of implementing the Commonwealth's strict environmental controls to be imposed on woodchipping and associated forest activities in Tasmania. However, the signing of the MOU by the Premier was premature as important issues to be addressed in the MOU had not been fully resolved at that time.

Senator Walters is not correct in saying that since January I have attempted to go back on agreement reached with Premier Gray by seeking to interfere with domestic forest operations in Tasmania. I assume Senator Walters is referring to the issue of forest operations in areas on the register of the National Estate. The Commonwealth in this respect has at all times been concerned to ensure, through the MOU, that Tasmania takes full account of the National Estate values in planning forest operations, be they for export or domestic purposes.

The Commonwealth is aiming to achieve its objective of protecting all environmental values, including those of national estate areas, while at the same time allowing woodchip export operations to continue in Tasmania, through a rational and professional process of consultation and agreement between the two Governments. This is reflected in the MOU itself which, I expect, will be finalised shortly.
Senator Walters may also wish to refer to my response to a Question Without Notice in the House of Representatives on 13 March 1986 on the same subject (Hansard page 1306).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 May 1986 (Hansard, page 2330), Senator Crichton-Browne asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned whether the Government has been able to confirm press reports of United States sales of rice to Papua New Guinea and action the Government is likely or able to take in respect of the matter.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following additional information.

As of 20 May 1986, no sales of US rice to Papua New Guinea had been reported by the US Department of Agriculture. Australian officials in the US are maintaining contact with US officials in this regard.

The purported rice sale to Papua New Guinea would be facilitated by US Government subsidies. In respect of rice, the subsidy of particular concern arises from the ``marketing loan'' provisions of the US Farm Bill rice program. These allow farmers participating in the program to repay Government loans at less than face value when, as is currently the case, the world market price is less than the mandated loan rate. In these circumstances, there is no mechanism to prevent particular markets being affected, unlike the export enhancement program in respect of which specific assurances were given to the Prime Minister during his recent visit to the US.

It remains of serious concern, however, that subsidised US rice could severely disrupt Australian rice exports to traditional markets. The Government will be using all appropriate avenues in bringing our concern to the attention of the US Government.
